author: oaklandmatt
content:
@everyone I just wanted to express gratitude to you all. This is the only place many of us have – on the internet or otherwise – that is a healthy, supportive, *non-political* community. author: oaklandmatt
JakeTB
content:
Hey all. Just wanted to say how much I appreciate this community and attest to the quality of conversation here.

I put in my resignation notice at the day job today, and will be transitioning to music full-time in May. I genuinely don’t believe I could have done it without this place. You all challenge me in the best ways, and have helped me grow tremendously as a person and a professional.

I still don’t have it all sorted out, and I’m still fervently pursuing mentorship in any form I can find, but for now the work is paying the bills; something I thought I’d never be able to say.

Thank you all for being generous with your hard-earned wisdom. It really does make a difference.

(Sorry, got a bit sappy there 😅)

author: oaklandmatt
NoahNeedleman
content:
So at the urging of Cian & Rauirí and a few other good friends, I took a full 3 months off when my daughter was born. During my paternity leave, my creative outlets were cooking, and photography. 

Photos are great cause you can snag a moment and then come back to it later to edit, cooking more difficult cause it takes time you might not always have. 

Well in typical captial C Creative fashion, i dug deep into it. I did a LOT of research and made some purchases and practiced a lot. Got some beautiful photos and captured some important memories. Really grateful for it. 

All that’s just backstory to say- everywhere else on the internet SUCKS. 

Reddit, Facebook, anywhere there are communities of people who are “trying to help,” it’s just full of tone deaf assholes with little info and a lot of bullshit to spew. And even the smart ones are 99% of the time tactless. 

Guys & girls, thank you for still being here. Best water cooler in the world: LWMR. 

Also I wish we had a photography channel.

author: sinaigimenez
content:
Today I got a reminder of how important love and care are in what we do. Just wanna give a shoutout to @Nomograph Mastering for all the wisdom shared here on that topic.

Long story short — I agreed to mix a track for an American rapper who had already been turned down by some A-list mixers, even though the guy had a decent budget. The reason was kinda obvious: he’s got a personality that leans toward OCD, with everything that comes with that — defensive tone in convos, super long mix notes, and weird stuff like thinking a file sounds different just because it was renamed. (I forgot to label one file as “ref. limited” like the previous versions, and even though it was literally the exact same file, he swore the “non-limited” one had a different top end.)

Stuff like that made me seriously consider walking away from the project like the others did — I could just feel the back-and-forth drama coming. But after my first instinct, I remembered a lot of what’s been talked about here: love, care, and being open to the music and the art. So I decided to try empathy instead of just being a jerk out of frustration.

And honestly? It worked. After taking a bit of time to really talk to him and show I genuinely wanted to help — not just as a mixer, but as a human — I learned he’s totally burnt out and running on fumes 'cause he just became a dad. And I totally get that, since my first kid was born a month ago too. That connection shifted the whole vibe. The next round of notes actually made sense, and we ended up approving the first mix by version 4 — which isn’t bad at all. Happy client, job done.

Not saying you should hang onto toxic clients, but it was a solid reminder: don’t always go with your first reaction. Sometimes just showing a little care  about the person on the other side can change everything. It did for me this time. And tbh, I don’t think I would’ve handled it this way if I hadn’t read some of the stuff shared here. So thanks, y’all. This place is gold.

author: BatMeckley
content:
So, early in working with Cavallo we we’re doing a project at Skywalker Ranch in Nor Cal, living there for about 6 weeks. And he would unwind by cooking the staff these huge dinners in the industrial kitchen and then when they all retired for the night he would crack a bottle of wine and just talk shop with me for an hour or two. One night we’re talking about mixers, and I mentioned doing a project with another producer where one of the big big big name mixers had tanked the record. And he said “well whose fault is that?” And I responded the mixers obviously, it was awesome when we sent it to him. And he said “no, with all due respect, it’s the producer’s job. I sent back *grammy winning record here* 12 times to that mixer because the mix was just not quite right. As a producer your only job at the end of the day is ‘can i stand behind this record, is this the best the artist could possibly put out. Does it rule’. THAT is the job of a producer. A guy like Fields might get there by re playing all the instruments when the band leaves. A guy like Rubin might give them a reading assignment. They’re both equally producers because at the end of the day their records are consistently quality, however they get there. THAT is the job. The rest is just details”

The people that know how will always work for the people that know why. 

That lesson was invaluable to me.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
📖 story time:

Arguably one of the most important things I did in my career was a last minute instrumental version of "I Love Rock N Roll" for an A&R at Syco in the US for some random contestant on the short-lived US version of the X Factor. I crushed it on a deadline, then that same A&R hired me a year later to work on a band called Emblem 3 who was on X Factor US as well. I crushed that and then six months after that he recommended me to a UK A&R who was having trouble finishing a song for One Direction. I did a spec production on the song Best Song Ever and they liked it and used it and all of a sudden I become a big pop producer. Stemming from doing an great job on some instrumental cover for a dumb singing tv show.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Without going too therapist couch on the details, I was the only kid that had to lie to my parents in highschool and tell them I was going to parties (which were ok) and then went to work playing shows on the sunset strip (which was banned). Moving to Australia to join a band in my early 20s got me excommunicated from half of my family, some of whom I didn’t get to talk to for nearly a decade. Some had credible experience in the industry, others just in life, but truthfully, if you care about someone’s quality of life and ability to provide for themselves and hopefully a family, you don’t steer them towards a career in music. 

But, I wouldn’t be told no, and every time I was pushed away from something I wanted to do (I couldn’t go to school in LA because it was too close to the industry) I ended up somewhere that actually furthered my career (I ended up in San Diego, where I became friends with the Switchfoot guys which really helped launch me). It’s why I have such little patience for the “oh the studio manager was short with me while I was an assistant” crowd… if you want it bad enough, you figure out a way to make it work. And if you don’t want it bad enough, there’s a hundred more guys like me that do, that are willing to sacrifice their time/health/money/etc to the cause. I don’t say that to frame it as admirable or healthy or anything positive, it’s just the truth of how things are. 

So, that person that’s going to quit because a studio manager was challenging, or a teacher didn’t like their song? They’re going to get devoured by the people that really dedicate their lives to this, and it feels cruel to tell them otherwise.

author: BatMeckley
content:
God I love this discord. 
To me 90% of the reason big producers are paying many thousands a day to be in a studio the past 15-20 years is to just not have to worry about shit. Anyone can make a record at home these days; part of being in an “actual” studio is the cocoon of creativity. If the assistant takes more than a couple of minutes to patch anything in, bring up the piano, or recommend the best Thai place in town, they’re blowing it. I had an assistant once at this place famous for making cookies on site, bring me my normal plate of cookies I always ask for and while I was comping I ate half of one, put it back on the plate, and continued working. He didn’t say a word, got up, grabbed the plate, and disappeared for a few minutes and came back. “Hey man, I know you normally house the entire plate of cookies so when you put that one back I checked with the kitchen and last week I guess they changed the cookie recipe, and they’re gonna make em like they used to for you.” 😂😂. I asked for that dude every session after, less for the cookies but more for the insane attention to detail and telepathy. One of max’s engineers started as a Conway assistant, and as good of an engineer as he was he also prepped the best Hookahs and was just a great hang. Max ended up hiring him for his own studio. We’re in a people business, try to be attentive and a good person to have around, for all the reasons that go beyond knowing how to set an attack on an 1176. 

The flip side is, if you’re booking a studio as a producer, the assistants are what really make the studio run. Treat them well. Know their names. Give them credit. No assistant on any session I ever did paid for their own meal, they got what the artist got.  They most of the time got engineer credits. Help them along. As with all things, mutual respect goes a long way.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Re; Brauer workshop

-First 2 days were nothing technical, the 1st conversation he brought up was about TM and how meditation in general has helped him.
-Everything is feel-based, most technical Q's for the first 2 and a half days got the same reply: "It doesn't matter to me, i don't care what the thing is long as it feels good". 
-MHB actually seems to leave the planet while he's mixing, it's wild how immediate he gets into that space. Seemed to go way past "i love mixing and here's all the reasons i'm the shit" and it was inspiring to see the ego leave the equation. His decades of experience are playing directly into his ability to access the story of the song and present it in a compelling, live-feeling way. He mixes from inside the song and performs. Well, he does discovery, then shapes the sounds, then performs just about everything on faders.
-The biggest wake up call to me is that a lot of moves i've made on mixes did not have a good reason behind them. So continuing to ask "why" as I work is gonna be important, because I have to start catching myself and adjusting when the answer to "why" is "because someone said this preset is cool" or "because this is what I do to a vocal/guitar/drums". I feel music very deeply, it's why i got into this, but I feel like i've been poisoned against trusting that instinct and convinced that what we do is a technical job. I'm done being an observer of the art, i want to be bold.
-It's critical to build trust with clients right away, you can't assume anything in what they understand about how you feel. Telling them you love the song and you're excited to mix it is important, and never blaming production/artist/anything else for the mix being less than what it should be. never okay to say "i did my best", because that gives you an out and implies somebody else could do it better
-Therefore, you must believe when you sit down to mix that nobody is gonna interpret this song better than you.
-Generally i'm skeptical to just take on someone else's "method" and start operating in that space just becuase of the success they've had with it. Putting this week into practice is going to mean using his template to get reps in, listening and feeling and interacting in a new way and letting my brain "level up", if you will, then zooming out and making it my own.


I can distill this more and want to share about a couple other specifics, but I just realized I grabbed someone else's notebook by mistake when I left on the last day so I'll need to have them mail mine back to me.

author: bobby k
content: sort of related, but i've been reflecting a lot on how precious it is to maintain a listener's perspective on a work in progress, and what things we can be doing as the producer/mixer/etc to grant that privilege to the artist first and foremost. the simple stuff includes saving the nitty gritty work for your own time, delivering the best mix of the record no matter the stage it's in, focusing any time spent together on how you can make their voice and contributions and ideas the best they can be. some artists love mixing and editing and getting into the weeds, but i'm realizing quite often how much of a duty it is to be the artist, and how record making is only a single slice of that pie. For us it is more or less the whole pie. and a big responsibility we carry (perhaps without realizing?) is that it is our job to protect the artist from getting  stressed out by the process. and this extends to processing and managing our own stress about the work should it exist, as stress is a contagious energy.

author: Zakhiggins
content:
I've had certain partners that are easier to deal with than others with this kind of thing for sure, and being with someone who actually understands these things really helps, but at the end of the day no one wants to be with someone who's grinding 100% of the time. There's more to life than that, and whats the point of being in a relationship if you never see the other person. I also get the working in music/freelance lifestyle, and sometimes its hard to even want to do fun things outside of it when you're so focused on this thing that really excites you that also is your livelyhood.

Its such a hard thing to get right and in my experience with certain partners, its been an ongoing arguement, even in the past when i've had salary jobs and a very predictable schedule. So i'm not sure it goes away by making your life more regimented. I think the only answer here is being super open and radically honest about everything. 

In my experience, letting your partner know when you've been asked to do something before you've agreed to it, makes them feel like they're a part of the thought process behind the work and less like they're just observing you living your life from the outside. Even if you were always gonna say yes to it anyway, at least they feel like they have some control and are on the same team as you. IME you just gotta go out of your way to make them feel like they're doing it all with you. They feel closer to you in a situation where they could just as easily feel like they're being pushed away. I'm not sure what way you've went about it, thats just my experience. If you're living with your partner you kinda have to see yourselves as the same person working toward the same thing, as opposed to two individuals with their own lives.

Also going out of your way to be spontaneous and do something fun and/or stupid like you're teenagers when things arent as busy goes a long way when things are.

author: philbarnes
content:
One of my favorite TLA experiences is when I (unknowingly) fucked up a drum edit in a song I sent him to mix about 6 years ago. 

Got a voicemail from a South Beach number that said "Phil! Tom Lord-Alge here. Hey, thank you for those stems. Give me a call when you get a chance would ya?" 

Not knowing my demise, I thought I would flex and call him in front of my gf on speakerphone where the first words out of his mouth were: "Thanks for sending those stems so fast. But these drums... are absolutely FUCKED. I could fix it for you, but I'm not going to, you're a professional engineer, figure it out." 

Needless to say I stayed up all night figuring it out, found my mistake and I like to think we're on better terms now.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Ok Tl;dr- where you are matters as much as who you are. 

I’m also from a small town, moved to LA trying to get famous and got my ass handed to me by artists who were better looking & more talented and yet were still struggling to be seen. But I kept at it because I’m tenacious, (read: delusional, as all artists must be.)

I was able to work *for* some of those artists cause I had a diverse skillset, and I was full time music after about 4 years, by the time I was 26. Doing gigs at hotels and playing guitar or recording for other people, teaching guitar, leading music at churches, all the while pouring evening last ounce of money & energy into my artist career, until my last real artist project broke up the week we were supposed to sign our first record deal. I was 36. 

That’s when I moved to Nashville and really gave myself over to music directing and producing and writing for other artists. I did it as a consolation while I regrouped to find my next thing, but for some reason, when I made the move all the sudden my whole career made sense to me. 

As it turns out, my real joy comes not from the sound of my own voice, but from helping others find theirs. When I acquiesced to that very real, very culturally counterintuitive calling, I thrived. 

All the sudden I was playing music with and for a bunch of my heroes, and all my friends who were artists starting getting famous. And (shocker) I was really glad I wasn’t one of them. 

I always thought that my calling was to help people feel less alone in the world, and that the music I made was the vehicle for that calling. In the end, it turns out it was the relationships i built through music that were the real vehicle.  

It took me a long time to figure out who I was, and the cities I was in played a huge role in that story. Nashville built its whole industry on people who want to *help* artists, not just *be* artists. 

I miss LA every day but I’m in the right place. So, my friend, where is the right place for you?

author: Rollmottle
content:
I’m not really sure what we’re talking about anymore, but:

Nobody’s entitled to make a living in any industry just because they feel like they should be able to. You earn your stripes by consistently providing value. The money will follow. 

I don’t agree engineers have more leverage today. The core skillset is a commodity. Being able to provide value above and beyond that (reliability, efficiency, good hang, developing a specialized skill or sound, etc) is where the money is. That doesn’t happen day 1 (see above). 

Focus on being good, exceptional, providing value instead of what you SHOULD be getting. I SHOULD be better looking, wealthier, skinnier, whatever....not doing me a whole lot of good spending any of my energy there.

author: LAPhill
content:
It's really hard to make decisions when you feel like our back is up against the wall. We've all experienced some degree of this, one way or another, and a lot of it comes down to personal tolerance for risk and resilience to weather dry spells, as well as our individual life circumstances.

There's no medal for going months without income. If you need to find a day job or side hustle to stay afloat, that's not failure. That's responsible. If the feeling of your wife's support is making you feel guilty, then it might be a signal to take some action to address that feeling. Music will always be there, and it's not an all-or-nothing proposition. 

I'm not trying to prescribe the way out of this, but give yourself some grace and permission to navigate it. You're not less-than because you take time to address your personal life and finances in the midst of building your career, you're human.

author: BatMeckley
content:
No. 
No no. 
No to the hell nah no. 
This is why I keep telling people how important it is to develop their taste. 
Alex shares similar sonic traits with his Dad because he grew up listening to someone go, “Christ there’s so much wooliness in this vocal, we need to get it up to where the audience can hear the words” or “let’s cut some space HERE in the track so that THIS sits”. The whole secret is the WHY, not the fact that he gifted him a MH Channel strip license. 

I’ve been really into photography lately, and I’m constantly struck by how my professional photographer little brother constantly gets better results than i do on worse gear. And it’s because he knows what to look for in a photograph, and then it’s easy enough to work backwards from there. That’s the skill of the whole thing. And it’s such a strong parallel to watching the Machine Head collectors on gearspace or the $12k PRS blues lawyers on TGP wax poetic about gear while clearly having no idea what the gear is actually used for. 

Focus on the right things.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Guess what? I’m going to be contrarian here.

I can only make music in a way that I consider “good”. I’m no good at figuring it out if you meant to make it suck. And I can’t hand back something that sucks. You’ve hired me to make it not suck, or at least suck less.  If you hire me to vocal produce, I won’t reprogram the drums. But I’m going to try and make that vocal kick ass. If you hire me to mix and an out of tune bass is fucking up the mix, I’m going to tune it. If the artist doesn’t like it, it could be a revision note. I’m open to that.  But what I’m not going to do is hand back a first pass that sucks because I’m trying to guess if the artist meant to suck. That would suck.

Things dont have to be perfectly in tune or on the grid; in fact they’re often better when they’re not. But if something actually sucks, fix it. If you’re not right for the gig, you’re not right for the gig, but go down swinging making it the best you thought it could possibly be. Trying to guess what the artist intended is a fools errand.

Make the things you work on better because you worked on them.

author: cian riordan
content:
While the 'science is settled' argument is often used to shut down discussion, it's also rooted in the idea that certain ideas have reached some form of scientific consensus -- usually rooted in findings more exhaustive than off the cuff anecdotal evidence. As somebody with a science background myself, my issue with Jon's claim is that its not rooted in any sort of methodical process. And now kids on the internet get fueled with the idea that one DAW might sound better than another -- instead of focusing on things that make far more of a difference in their productions/mixes/masters/etc.

EDIT: I Have no doubt that if the same person mixed the same song in two different DAWs that they’d come to very different results. But that’s all inherent to the workflow, not to the physics or limitations of that particular DAW.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Growing up in Ireland, without PP I wouldn’t have known that making records could be a legitimate career.

It showcased real life *professionals* working at a high level, and was my introduction to the discourse around the industry. Having only experienced studio work as a cottage industry up to that point, PP opened my eyes to avenues I could pursue that I wouldn’t have known even existed otherwise (recording engineer is different to mixing engineer is different to producer is different to songwriter??!). It all seems very rudimentary now, but I was starting from literally nothing in a place with few (if any?) visible role models.

I learned so much from it on a technical level - from basic stuff like what a Pultec is and how people use it (connecting the dots between my cracked Waves bundle - Puigtec and who tf JJP was), what “a vocal chain” might look like and the purpose of each stage…

True, the interviews did become unbearable, but there was a golden era between eps around 30-90 at a time when outside of working in the studio world, there weren’t many other sources of good information from people who were really doing it.

Huge appreciation for Dave, and I hope he and his family get the support they need.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I dreamt last night that Eric Valentine turned out to be a hacky, big on YouTube but where are his credits type character. 

He'd leveraged the LWMR discord to sell 1,200 tickets to a 1 day masterclass type event, and had drawn all these people out to a field where he'd set up a huge marquee but no PA.

When the session started, he had a projector showing his screen but it was too small, and nobody could hear what he was talking about, or what he was playing back from his laptop speakers. At the lunch break, a single intern was serving unidentifiable yellowish slop to a huge queue of people on cheap paper plates. The people in the queue were all disappointed but trying to remain positive.

In the queue, Eric walked past grinning, and when I asked how he was doing, he said "can you believe it? I'm making $200 an hour today!!". 

Given everything I'd heard from @cian riordan and @oaklandmatt, I really expected more of Eric.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Loving your job 80% of the time is a phenomenal, compared to the general public. 

One thing I’m amazed by working with Cian & Rollmottle is their endless capacity for positivity during a project. No matter how shitty my delivery or communication, they approach things with a smile and a sense of humor. I’ve literally never heard either of them complain. I thought commiserating about shitty aspects of a gig was a part of professionalism, but they have me rethinking things. 

In my own projects, when I approach clients with patience and curiosity, I find that not only are they happier faster, I’m happier the whole time. It’s SO MUCH EASIER to say “let’s try it” than to say “here’s why that’s not a good idea.” I find I learn a lot that way too. 

In any case, going back in to fix or add only bugs me when I think I’m supposed to be done. If I can stay open, then opening a session feels a lot easier. 

So I guess my advice is: you might have fewer problem clients if you try to remember they’re not problems to solve, they’re people to serve.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Love the whole conversation above. 

One thing to consider with the whole “people hire me for my taste” thing is that it’s important to have not only a refined palate, but also a broad enough one to be collaborating. 

I’ve worked with extremely talented people who don’t have the breadth to apply their skills to something even slightly outside of their *exact* preference, and I perceive that as being to their detriment. 

If you want to be a professional chef and you make incredible arrabbiata but begrudgingly phone it in with alfredo, you’re going to have a pretty poor career telling Italian restaurants that you’re the right guy for arrabbiata and the wrong guy for alfredo. That’s niching down a little too hard a little too early.

I think it’s our job to find the essence within something and maximally bring that essence out. Often these “taste mismatch” issues come across to me as missing that essence within the thing you’re working on and trying to make it something that it essentially isn’t. ie. A wannabe Max Martin working with a wannabe mitski and the producer complaining that the artist’s suggestions are making the production hashy and the artist complaining that the producer’s production choices don’t convey enough emotion. 

It’s talking past each-other and not really collaborating. You aren’t learning to truly love what your partner loves, which IMO is frankly a big part of the job.

content: I’ve spent that last two years almost exclusively mixing and I’m starting to feel a bit bored. For whatever reason, the lane I’ve ended up in (and the skill set I’ve honed) is taking less than ideal recordings and productions, and making them sound professional. I often find myself thinking “if I was recording this, I would have done xyz”. So it’s time to get back into the studio and get things right from the start. Mixing full time is also quite lonely. Pre covid, I was used to being surrounded by interesting, creative people… now most of my interactions are remote. And despite Jon and some other people’s thoughts, I find in person revision sessions to be inefficient and usually unfruitful. So, time to record some stuff.

author: cian riordan
content: Priority for me when working at an outside studio is to befriend and endear thr assistant. Make it clear that i have their back… and usually itll amount to them having mine.

author: cian riordan
content:
The take-way from all this blibber blabber is that I went in expecting to be trusted immediately. I wanted to show off… to establish ‘status’ as Ruairi put it. But it took years of patiently learning the ropes at the highest level to be trusted by the folks in the highest circles. I look back upon that now and I’m still amazed that I was paid to do that. It was essentially like a paid college degree in making records.

So now when I go into studios with a big client, I see the assistant through those eyes. I’m kind but communicative. If they can hang in the back and figure out how I work, anticipate breaks — get the menu book ready — know that we’re going to change gears — start setting up for that — then they get looped in. They get my running commentary on what techniques I’m doing. They get the inside baseball… “I wish they fired this fucking drummer”. 

I agree with Ruairi that this type of coming up through the ranks is a loss for up and comers. It was tried and true way to make people understand the ins and outs of studio technique, etiquette, professionalism. I’m glad I got to ride one of the last waves of it. I wouldn’t be here making records at this level if it weren’t for the opportunities I had at the bottom levels of the industry.

author: LAPhill
content:
To piggyback on @cian riordan 's point, there are real, tangible benefits to being quiet in the back of the room. I would love to be a fly on the wall while @BatMeckley is producing a chart-topping vocalist, or see how Cian works through a first pass of a mix for his next Grammy-winning client. I guarantee they've learned a thing or two about how to talk to sensitive, demanding, highly respected artists. And they've learned how to interpret vague feedback ("make the vocal less green")  and working with people who can't articulate what they want. These are things you can't learn by watching Youtube videos or going to school.

When I was an assistant at Remote Control, getting to sit in and see how Hans handles a note from Jerry Bruckheimer taught me more than years of music education. Watching my boss struggle for 6 months on a 10-minute cue and then sit in a meeting with grace and calm while he's being told to change everything he just spent many long nights working on. 

That's not to mention things like learning how the real pros handle file management, deliveries, deadlines, tech problems, etc.. There is so much beyond learning the gear that comes from being a good assistant. If Matt knows you're going to shut up AND have his back with lackluster cookies, he's going to let you hang in the room longer. Which means you can absorb and learn more. It's a win-win.

author: BatMeckley
content: I feel like virtually all of us are dealing with mental health issues in one way or the other. For me, getting out of my own way is not over analyzing every step I take and re-litigating every mix decision to the point where I end up only releasing a handful of songs every few years.  At some point, no matter what our individual issues are, we have to log off the internet and actually make music instead of constantly talking about all of the individual reasons why we can’t. Sometimes, at least in my case, we get analysis paralysis because it’s easier than actually hitting record and just doing the damn thing. There was this meme going around last week that was something along the line of “oh hey task that only took me 15 minutes but I’ve been putting off for 5 months”. I think we can all get caught up in bathing in the 58 reasons why we can’t do something instead of just locking on to the few reasons we can, because it’s safer to live in our potential than our actual.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Ok I'm gonna go in depth about this because I think it's FASCINATING.

The top three songs have an overlapping core fanbase that is largely unrepresented (or maligned) in popular culture: the white working class.

But none of them are really straightforward "country." 

The first song is a viral hit that seemingly comes from an authentic Appalachian kid talking about class. Despite his very explicit statements about hating political division, it has of course been wildly politicized because everything on the internet is these days.

The second song is a white male country singer covering a black lesbian female's iconic song ALSO about class. Talk about intersectionality...

The third song is the longest running solo male #1 song on the Hot 100 from the biggest star in country music (and really one of the biggest stars in the world... just, again, not covered by the current fashion of mainstream culture). It's a kinda-country-but-kinda-just-pop song co-written by the biggest country writer in history (Ashley Gorley) as well as once-rapper-and-Dr-luke-protege J Kash.

The rest of the chart is interesting too. #4 is a four year old taylor swift song that has gained traction online from her current tour so the label started pushing it as a single. 

There are two Olivia Rodrigo songs, signaling a true new superstar.

There are two songs from the Barbie soundtrack. In a "dying" movie industry currently on strike, when is the last time two songs from a movie soundtrack have been in the top 10? I dunno.

And lastly, there's only 1 trap song. The majority of these songs are people playing real instruments and writing more "classic" singer-songwriter songs. Rap music is really having a lull after a decade of dominance.

author: cian riordan
content:
"Sorry about the late night duplicate file, I did this track after six other people because I'm rushing as a team player.   I delivered as promised up front as we are all in overtime now to make it great.  *CLIENT* is happy with your work and with mine and we are all working overtime together.   Apologies also, I know there were some annoying ticks in there with some of the revised files. Still not sure why this one session did that. 

Of course I don't listen to every single file, post rendering.   We render and send 500-1000 files a month with the revisions on the 200-300 monthly songs that I do.  Team players don't ask such things on CC.  I work usually 7 days a week for 40-50 people a month, and making them happy with great masters is job #1.  Perfectionism is not a part of that process.    Software makes mistake, and that's ok.    People make mistakes and that's ok.   Mixes and masters should never aim for perfect, they should aim to connect, aim for humanity.  

Perfection is not the goal here, it's musicality and teamwork.  I'm sorry your ears suffered that horrible popping, but please, be cool. "

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
For my day job (which I leave in 2 weeks for music fuuuuck 😱) I create presentations and eLearnings for some big companies. 

There’s a neat framework called Bloom’s Taxonomy which I use all the time to benchmark the value of the learning objectives. If what you’re “teaching” doesn’t link with one of these, you’re probably not teaching. And on the hierarchy you want to ideally be closer to the top. The lower you go, the less applicable the thing is and the less useful.

Many of these entertainment videos masking themselves as learning videos probably correspond with the lowermost rung on the taxonomy when I think about it. You’ll go away recalling basic concepts and ideas but not creating, evaluating, applying it etc…

author: BatMeckley
content:
I think I’m more along the lines of Seth, in that I firmly believe that in an ultra competitive field like making music, if you don’t have that fire within you, the faith in yourself to keep going even if someone doubts you, it’s probably not going to work out very well for you long term. Success in our (and frankly most fields) isn’t given, it’s taken. There were so many people, some incredibly close to me, that insisted I was going fail. Frankly, if they hadn’t, I don’t know if I would’ve had the success I’ve had so far. When you’re flat broke, behind on rent, car is broken, and no one is hiring… “fuck you” can be an awfully powerful motivator.

That doesn’t mean it’s our job to spit on others dreams… I believe in proactively reaching out to the up and comers because believing in someone and supporting them can be incredibly powerful. But if you NEED that kind of validation constantly to get the work done… not a good sign.

If you ever get the chance, you should show your mom how Ozone works. It would blow her mind.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
@Nomograph Mastering said a thing in #deleted-channel (go read it, it’s for everyone really) that resonated with another lesson I learned annoyingly late.

Ruarí: “For years I would open conversations by telling people how much I loved LA, and that I was here to learn. Shock horror a bunch of people opened up and taught me a bunch of shit”


My version in a sentence: “**Open mouths get fed.**”

If you want to learn something from someone, or you want a job, or whatever, or you’re engineering writing sessions when you really want to be writing - people will not guess these things. Get used to asking (respectfully, etc) and being clear about what you want, and more often than not (IME) people will be happy to help you, or send you in the right direction.

It won’t apply to everyone, but I wish I’d realised it way earlier.

author: Zach Hughes
content: Story time. Last night me and my gf saw Janelle Monáe on her age of pleasure tour at the Ryman here in Nashville. While she was making her entrance on stage something weird happened to the sound. Loud pop, clicking, and then no signal, but seemed like the in-ears / on stage monitoring were still working. Her and the band played through the entire first song while everyone in the audience was just looking around confused. Many heads turning to the sound board. Eventually the crowd started a 'we can't hear you' chant and Janelle and the band realized what was going on. They all calmly walked off stage. Took maybe ten minutes for it all to get sorted with the sound. Then Janelle and her band proceeded to come back out redo the entire intro / first song and give maybe the greatest live performance I've ever witnessed. The show ended with a double encore. It felt like such an amazing example of class and professionalism. I got the sense that she decided, after walking off the stage the first time, that not a single person in the audience will remember this show being anything but amazing and it was. Truly undeniable. If anyone here has a chance to catch any of the remaining shows on her tour, I could not recommend it enough. 🤘

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Coincidentally I was exploring a similar idea this morning. I'm on a David Bohm kick and was reading his book 'On Dialogue' and recently finished his 'On Creativity' (would highly recommend both).

In 'On Dialogue' he gives an example I think can be repurposed here. Imagine a song being presented to us. An external signal. When it reaches us it makes contact with what Bohm calls the "whole movement of thought". The thinking and feeling apparatus within us is activated. Thoughts and 'felts' are said to be fundamentally created from memory. Upon contact a 're-presentation' is created where the activity of our thought and feeling reforms the event internally. The 'net presentation' is the fused result. 'Mis-representation' occurs when we mistake the 'net presentation' for the original.

I was thinking on all this and how it might connect to your comment from yesterday, "I told Jon that I don't think he's ever brought more to an album, but also left less of his fingerprints on it".

Bohm brings up Michael Polanyi's idea of tacit knowledge. This is the always running in the background implicit structure we attend to music from, which makes 're-presentation' possible. This includes nostalgia for records we love, perceptual training, bodily memory, tolerance for brightness, etc... Implied here is that this is something you cannot turn off but can cultivate greater awareness off in disciplined participation with art. Polanyi says we attend from subsidiaries to a focal whole. If you start attending to your own sonic fingerprint as the focal object, the structure may collapse. So perhaps Jon was able to integrate a remarkable tacit contribution while being sensitive to the pre-existing structure and coherence of the whole. Maybe coherence and truth have similar meanings here?

Downstream of the artist's origination maybe 'truth' in record making is deep tacit integration, suspending egoic domination, and sensitivity to the internal structure / coherence of the original whole.

author: Karim
content:
This was resolved today! Sharing what I learned in case anyone encounters a similar situation:

–  Meta has an internal tool called “Oops” to address issues (like accidental bans) for friends and family.

– Access to Oops has become significantly more restricted since the pandemic because some employees began selling access to it. 

– Your best option is to connect with someone at Meta who still has direct access or knows someone who does.

– Labels (even small ones) typically have a direct line to a Meta industry representative with access. 

– Unless you personally know someone at Meta who genuinely cares about your situation, the industry rep is likely the only person with an incentive to keep music/audio folks happy. You'll just have to provide them your handle, a detailed account of what happened that they can forward to Oops, and a new email that you've never used with any Meta platform.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Ironically, my career always seems to go best when my back is up against the wall. There’s that extra gear that panic gives me that helps me lift the car off my leg or put up with Cian or do whatever else seemed impossible  at first glance. 

Once I got out of college I spent my days selling clothes to the rich and thin before I got enough music work to leave that gig. We all go through the 40 hour week of day job and 60 hour week  of music making grind at one point of our career or another. And even when you get to quit the day job, almost everyone I know in our business has gone through what i call the “Cell service rack”, where you get a couple of gigs and your rack gets filled with cool gear and then all of the sudden it’s quiet for a few months and there gets to be less gear in those racks as you sell things to make rent. It looks like the changing meter of how much cell signal you have. There’s no shame in that game. 

For better or worse, it never ends either. I know 9 figure millionaires that are like “maybe I need to get rid of the fifth house in Aspen and free up some capital”. There’s nothing wrong with proactively taking stock of your life every once in a while and re evaluating which particular juice is worth the squeeze.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult

That way it's less about the state of whatever industry (ie Spotify/AI doomer stuff) and more about the fire you've cultivated and keep cultivating every day, that you can harness how you see fit.

When I see musicians who are really ~doing it~, like so many in this discord, I see people who could easily be successful in a wide array of fields, and I hope y'all feel how extraordinary that type of dedication and drive is

author: Rollmottle
content: Many songs come out of the mixing stage sounding "done." Those songs could still benefit from perspective. I would not describe that as "a lot of the mastering processes happening in the mixing stage." For me, mastering is the process by which I 100% align the final product with the artistic intent. There's a technical component to that, but there's also a huge component of that that is pure vibe. Can I enhance the feeling of this song without getting in the way? Is the feeling of this song fully realized? Is the feeling of these songs together fully realized? Uncovering all that to me is the job. Sometimes it's already there and there's very little, if anything, to do. The perspective is still valuable. The key here is somebody who both understands the technical aspects of the job as well as somebody who can internalize and FEEL the music. The latter is why I believe mastering is one of the most misunderstood processes.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I'm totally with you on all this.

The question for me is less about the credit/ title, and more about the role. How do you get perspective at the end of the record making process? This role is changing, and we'd all be smart to understand where it's headed.

I get hired to finish songs a lot. Usually that means I have a "co-producer" credit. Sometimes it means "mixer" credit. Occasionally it's included "mastering." But really what I'm hired for is that combination of experience and technical knowledge. I'm an outside ear who knows how to fix what's missing. This role of "finisher" is really where a lot of the producer/ mixer/ mastering engineer profession is headed. The distinction between those roles is getting blurrier. 

Mixing engineers have moved from pulling up faders on the console and creating a mix (old school "mixers") to often just pulling up the rough mix of stems and making finishing touches (Jon, Manny, Serban, Tony, Bainz, etc.).

In this way, the "mixing engineer" profession is moving away from manipulating raw sounds to manipulating nearly finished mixes. This is sounding more and more like what a "mastering engineer" does. Now there's "stem mixing" and "stem mastering" too, further blurring the lines. These are all just slightly different configurations of the same thing. Who do you hire to get perspective and then act on it?

Those of us that are finishers or mixers or mastering engineers or whatever would be smart to think about how to adapt to the direction this is all headed. 

I want us all to win. I think we need to step back and expand how we think about the roles. It's the best way for us all to have careers.

author: BatMeckley
content:
This is such an unpopular take, but the people that I know that are truly great are making a living at it. Maybe not as much as they “should” (sometimes if I want to hate my life I imagine what my house would look like if the success I had was in the 80s and 90s and not the last 15 years) but again, it really does come to doing actually great work. “Work harder, suck less”. Ruqaurphï’s advice is really the best advice: focus, and bust ass. There’s a limited amount of slots out here of people that get to make a living out of what most do as a hobby; someone out there is willing to out hustle you and will lap you no matter how much of a head start being gifted gave you.

The other day I had brought up in the monitoring thread about how the quality of work has been diluted by how easy it is now to do adequate work. The “my cousin has a 5D, he can shoot your wedding for $50!” problem. Yet Glenn Luchford still gets 6 figures for photo shoots. Quality wins.

Yesterday I got to hang with Zack Cervini’s gf at a baby shower. Zack just bought a house. Cause he’s been kicking everyone’s ass at a certain genre of mixing and took his “internship to asst to fuck you pay me” mixer path seriously. There is still money to be made.

author: chrissorem
content: Possibly, I’ve encountered far more people that make the record making process about them. “My process” is a cringe word for me.  When your skill set gets to a certain level  people will let you know by either continuing to hire you or physically tell you what your strengths are. And your strengths are probably what you are most passionate about and what you put the most care towards. I’m not sure I see any benefit in sitting around and thinking about what yours strengths are. Rather be present pay attention  and learn how to be proactive and supportive to the artist you are working with. The combination will lead you working more. And your strengths will grow with time. I do understand some people lack confidence and for me I’ve become more confident with experience and success

author: Chase H
content:
@franc.castillejos 
I’m in Milwaukee which is by no means an LA or a Nashville.

I’m getting closer to being able to go full time mixing and doing some recording/producing in this small town by honestly just going out to shows of artist I enjoy and networking with them on a personal level, not even bringing up me mixing or recording for them.

Fulltime will  mean different things to different people but to me that means being able to support myself, my future wife (I get married in May) and our future children being able to stay at home full time without my wife having to work.

I haven’t worked on anything big but I love Music and being able to be in service of someone else putting out their vision.

I was close to moving to Nashville last year as I have a good amount of connects but for my life it wasn’t the right thing,

This may not be worth much because I’m by no means a heavy hitter engineer like some of the people here but maybe it’s a good idea for you  to DEFINE what success is to you, and then work backwards from there.

Wherever you end up I’m sure there will be a community of artists that you gel with and over time can work with and help them present their art

author: Rollmottle
content:
I have a career-level day job and have always viewed myself as an outsider as it relates to the industry. I have a deep passion and commitment to music and my day job allows me to pursue it the way I’ve always envisioned it. I am not in a position life-wise to financially struggle through finding my footing in the industry as a full-time pursuit, but I take it as seriously as if I had to. The practice of mastering, the way I envision it, is fucking expensive and my day job allows me to do it the way I see it. And like others, it allows me to choose the projects I wish to engage with and put out a quality product that aligns with my values. 

I struggle with imposter syndrome being an “outsider” but that’s never not been a thing for me as a creative. Just comes with the territory.

You’ve hit the cheese on the head.

author: Slow Hand
content:
---

At the end of the day I suppose I'm motivated to make music because what I want is not being represented anywhere else or I feel that I have something worth saying. I'm not aiming to be contrarian, but I want to follow the song and see where it leads me. I want to be surprised. Very often that runs counter to conventional wisdom around writing songs in "a way that people actually like."

Sometimes I feel as if I'm out here in the woods building a tiny little cathedral just for myself and a small group of people who stumbled upon it. If they wander in I'll serve them a nice meal and then send them on their way.

That said, I also don't have any expectation that I deserve to find success. I'm not going to get grumpy when my art doesn't pay off for me. I've got no illusions there. If somebody wants to make money in music they shouldn't be surprised when their Appalachian EDM doo-wop opera fails to find an audience. But if they make it I'd sure love to hear it.

author: Adam Thein
content: Re: overbooking/crunch times - I can’t afford a full time assistant or even a part time but I recently started hiring another engineer to help me out of these jams - and it’s great to be able to share your workflows and have someone learn what you need in order to help you when the sauce is getting thick.  Had a client reach out with a tight 2 day deadline right ahead of a move and I passed politely and recommended another engineer who said yes then bailed on the project 24 hours later It was my word so I jumped in and hired my other friend to split the fee with me and we got a royal amount of editing done in 24 hours and I got my client hooked up and happy.  Sometimes you gotta compromise your plans big time to make it happen.  If you can afford to build in spare days at your rate best to do that and then if you are ahead of schedule sneak in lighter quick turn work.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I hope that’s what comes across, because that’s certainly what I mean. Just want to make sure that the messaging reflects the meaning.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So I’m with Beckley on this. I get hired because of my taste, and I go into projects with full communication re: what is intended. 

I don’t say “this sucks I’m gonna fix it.” I say “I have some ideas about how to pull this into a really kickass place.” 

Very rarely as a mixer am I *only* mixing. Bass comes in and has no booty? Chances are I’m gonna be doing more than bx-subsynth to make it thump. Only tracked one guitar and it’s supposed to be huge? I’m gonna add some to really make that sell. 

I don’t always assume I know more than the artist, but the truth is, with the level of artists I usually work with, MOST of the time I do. 

That’s not an ego trip, it’s an understanding of the gig. It’s why people hire me. Why they ask for my help. And I treat that with deep respect. 

Last night Rauirí basically bullied me into buying RX standard for a project I was doing as a favor to a friend. I SPENT MONEY to do this thing. Because as Rauirí says: “Art matters.” 

And as Beckley ranted yesterday, I don’t think we should let something suck because we were only hired for a job. We’re not house painters who decided to fix a furnace. We’re general contractors who know how a house is built, and we fix shit that’s broken. (Bad example, but you get it.)

author: Slow Hand
content:
Fun question! I hate to complicate an already nuanced premise at the outset, but when I observe my own choices and think of each category I see myself living both sides of all three spectrums, but in different domains:

**For example:** I could be short-term in career objectives and overt achievement and long-term oriented in relationships and satisfaction. Cutting edge in creative pursuits, but classics in my personal taste. Specialist in my mode of expression, and generalist in my interests.

The more I subdivide and examine the question the more I find exceptions to everything. I am steeped in knowledge, but I seek wisdom above most things, which some philosophies would consider contradictory.

This Anais Nin quote comes to mind:

> "We do not grow absolutely, chronologically. We grow sometimes in one dimension, and not in another, unevenly. We grow partially. We are relative. We are mature in one realm, childish in another. The past, present, and future mingle and pull us backward, forward, or fix us in the present. We are made of layers, cells, constellations."

I think people are extremely lopsided and unbalanced when you start to drill down into their psyches, and that's wonderful! 

For the sake of refining this question and narrowing the scope, should we confine these three axis to only record making? Or do we want to approach it in a holistic sense?

author: Halliemmelton
content:
More of a generalization but work has taught me to practice patience, which has affected my life in a positive way. 

From the outside in, I have learned in life not to put yourself down or get in a bad mood over perceived “failure”. Pick yourself up and just don’t make the same mistake again, or if it’s less specific, just /do better/. I try not to think too much about anything I wish I’d done differently in the past, and I think I do a pretty good job about it—and that affects my work in a very positive way because I am learning as I go, and just constantly improving and getting my ego out of the way of it. It makes me better at the art side of things, and also makes me more efficient. I think about that aspect a lot

author: BatMeckley
content:
I’ve always gone with the (very true) “I don’t think I’m the guy that can push this particular track forward. I want to make sure you’re stoked on the end result and I don’t think my particular skill set is going to get you there. I’d love to recommend you to A,B,C who could probably do a better job with this”. Two things happen: 1) the artist respects you for genuinely caring about their outcome and not just doing a money grab, and 2) you’re in the position of helping your contemporaries get work. The thing I’m most proud of in my discography is that most people I work with I work with more than once, and that’s a direct result of the amount of work I turn down.

Just don’t send anything to @cian riordan

author: LAPhill
content:
There was a line in The Assistant's Handbook that we were required to read at Berklee. Something to the effect of "the only people that will understand you are other engineers, and who would want to marry one of them?" 

In all seriousness, there are plenty of people that are doing this full-time that have partners and families. Speaking only for myself, my wife has zero musical background. It's frankly really nice at the end of a long day to listen to what she's been up to, or talk about any of the things we connect on besides music and turn work-mode off. The right person will understand your passion and support you, they don't have to live it themselves. But you also need to show up and support them in their own endeavors and interests. It'll make you a more well-rounded human.

author: Andy Lawson
content: just taking a break from a mix.. i missed a lot.. the only thing i know is the harder i have worked, the better the industry has been to me.. i started with nothing,  zero $$$$ in my bank account (i did have a photocopied version of the pro tools manual),zero skills, zero training (apart from listening to every song i could)living in a tiny share house room with no windows. but i've slogged and slogged. i've always wanted to be the best at what i do and i carry that with me daily. am i the best, absolutely not. but everyday i go into battle and try to believe i am or want to kick someone else's ass.. it's got me to the point where i bought a house and support my family. i think without that mindset i would have given up on this job years ago. The industry does not play fair and never will, but i firmly believe you can play fair. i've never tried to steal a job from a friend, sneak my way into something. i've just tried to be open and honest with my clients and peers. that's my word vommit on reading above.. lol.... Workhard, Think big, Enjoy! that's all we've got

author: joshbonanno
content: i think the premise of this stems from the constant fight that i feel like we all face....wanting something to be the "best" it can be (at least in our personal minds and perspectives) vs the sometimes reality that we are hired to do a "job" and not everything is going to meet our expectations of what we personally think is great, because at the end of the day, we aren't the artist...or in some cases, even the intended audience. with that said...if someone is looking to hire me and my immediate gut says "this isn't great, everyone before me did a bad job and i am going to have to save the day" i immediately question if i am even the right person for the job as thats obviously not an attitude i really want to bring in to a collaborative process with others constantly thinking badly about everyone before me. / might mean i just dont understand the record itself. in the cases that i do take the job though, i typically just try and shift my mindset to think and assume that it made it to me this far and everyone signed off on it...so who am i to say its "bad" or needs fixing outside of what i was hired to do? maybe the bad vocal comps and slightly off time drums made it through the production stage because they liked the raw human nature of it? maybe their idea of life/color/mojo is different than mine and they're more sensitive to certain sounds etc....idk. this is maybe mainly more of a response pertaining to what i do as primarily mixing day in and day out and maybe doesn't translate as much to the production world...but i still think theres some connected ideas in that line of thinking. if the artist is happy with a sloppily played acoustic take that feels uninspired...you re-tracking and double tracking guitars that are on the grid and feel exciting to you doesn't always make it "better" in the artists mind or vision.

author: Nick Stetina
content: Congrats! The “worst” day in audio has been better than my “best” days at my old day job. That’s never lost on me. Excited for you!

author: Rob Domos
content:
Had a great experience today of hearing records that I previously thought sounded bad sound great out in the world. 

You know those Latin dance records where the drums sound like icepicks? I went to a restaurant that was blasting that shit but it was coming from speakers that were installed in their tall ass ceilings so the treble was 90 degrees off axis and traveling far. Shit sounded amazing. Like perfectly balanced on some tracks. It made me wonder if that kind of speaker setup might be more common in Latin America and these engineers are balancing things correctly for their common venue playback.  

It’s got me questioning what I think I know and makes me want to get deeply acquainted with a wider variety of playback scenarios/environments.

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
This is a great conversation and it’s super interesting to see how culture and geography influences it.

As a Brit, the class system very much underpins life, even now (but in much different, more complex ways), so I share some of @Deleted User’s sentiments as the game is often rigged against a large portion of the populace despite their best efforts to turn things around for themselves. If only we had pure meritocracy here. Sam Fender put it really well this week with regards to the music industry so I won’t go over stony ground, you can google his thoughts which I largely relate to.

As an individual I’m horribly determined and annoyingly persistent when I have a goal in mind, as well as always balancing that with being the kindest person I can be towards others (sometimes to my detriment) and pretty much always in a headspace of bettering myself personally and professionally. This has generally been the key to many of the opportunities I’ve been given. There’s an English word for it, “nous”, which I think is similar to agency but also encompasses the notion of having “good sense”. I quite like that as it’s less about intelligence, and more about personal character. Just my two cents. As always firing off quick thoughts in a session break so I’m sorry if my take is a bit disconnected.

author: Dereck Blackburn
content: My 2c: from August 2024 to October 2025 I worked with an artist where they brought me bones of songs and we co-wrote an albums worth of work together. They moved from the city to central massachusetts and while the songs and mixes are about 80% done, they can't get above water time and travel wise to finish the project and its put on hold for next year. This is a big record for me as a producer and musician, and it sucks that I put so much time and effort into it but in the end, I hope waiting it out  and getting back to refocus in 2026 will be worth it. On the other hand, I get hired by a band, they are super intense and ambitious about recording, mixing, and releasing - the album comes out and they breakup in 3 months or theres a lineup change where the new drummer has a home studio and can record everything there and mix it then 6 months later I get a IG dm to bail them out becuase the drummer fucked the guitarists wife and the bass player and vocalist are just going to finish the record on their own with me.

author: Berlin
content:
I found last year really focusing on a morning routine for myself (self care, if you will) helped me to stay positive. At least I am taking care of myself first and that is all something I can control. Then I can take on the variables and unknowns of the day. Makes for a late start for me now (to which, I'm still adjusting)... but I feel fully ready to face the day every day. Nothing in the back of my mind lingering, letting myself down.. 

Additionally I have let my self imposed work hours go, just freeing myself to be open to the art life as it comes, any hours of the day. Trying to bottle everything into a 9-5 was difficult for me.. why are artists calling me at 9pm? Well.. that's when they are off from their day job and can talk. I took that boundary away for myself and felt some self imposed frustration melt away. Grateful for the calls, emails, texts, DMs.. any hours. Bring it on. 

Both of these changes have helped my attitude and optimism AND HOPE of a future in music and art.. Continuing this on into 2026.

author: spectrummasters
content:
This completely resonates with me. The business of music doesn’t sit as well with me as the business of construction. There’s a camaraderie and kinship in physical labour on construction projects, and an embodied intelligence in that world that offsets the subjective and (for me) atomised work of hours alone mixing.

When I’m doing construction work, I’m also free to think objectively and from a distance about my audio engineering work.

Most of all, something changes for me when I’m being paid for musical “work” that I’m not entirely happy with. I’ve discussed this privately with a few folks here, and it seems the relationship between music and its commodification is problematic for more than a few of us. Simply put, it’s sometimes less enjoyable — though equally amazing — being paid for a passion.

I couldn’t recommend a construction or skilled trade career enough. It’s incredibly flexible and offers a tonic to music careers: you know you can walk onto a site tomorrow and get paid quickly and well. It’s always going to be around, and in my case, the certifications allow me to consider migrating to most economies globally as a skilled worker.

Construction allows me to be my own patron for my musical endeavours, and that feels really good.

I’d love to see a bigger debate here about how working in the upper echelons of the music industry feels long term — challenges, payoffs, economics, job security, retirement, healthcare, family life versus work life, and a world where socialising is networking.

Construction is a simpler engagement: competency, find a solution, do the work, go home.

I came across @cian riordan discussing becoming a fireman on Conversations, and much of what you said, Cian, is exactly what I get from construction.

I love how for you, though — instead of the firehouse bell calling, it was multiple Grammys!

author: BatMeckley
content: I was 18 when I got invited into studio A at oceanway and a producer I was working with showed me that and it was my “oh shit people take this job SERIOUSLY” moment and I knew I had to get my shit together.

author: LAPhill
content: My advice: Get a mortgage payment that you can handle paying even if you go a few months without working, factor that into your calculation of how much house you can afford. And keep some money tucked away because things WILL come up that need to be fixed urgently from time to time. Going up to, or over, how much house you can afford will force you into taking jobs you don't want to take when things go even a little bit sideways.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Nah. That's great. 

I still remember my very first studio internship where I was assisting. The owner walked me into the control room and the first thing he told me was "Rule No. 1: Don't open your fucking mouth. If you have an idea, keep it to yourself. This room is going to have enough opinions in it as is and nobody needs another idea in the mix."

He probably said it (a little) nicer than that, but the message was unambiguous.

author: Barbara
content:
Honestly, the easiest way is to lower your expectations on how much people can understand what drives you. I don't see myself doing that, though. 

If you're not willing to show without making an effort that the most "unlovable" aspects of the job drive you as much (if not more) than having your name on an A-list project, it's gonna be hard for other people to understand what it means to you. I believe it's as difficult as it is for me to understand why people work in finance or IT. Don't take it personal, try to take it easy...

author: LAPhill
content:
Why was it something you were comfortable putting your name on before, but not now? Unhappy with the outcome?

Many people earlier in their careers seem really hung up with being attached to the less than stellar projects. The reality is that the world really doesn't care. When you get your big hit, everyone's going to want to work with you and no one is going to look up that one song you did 3 years ago that was pretty shitty.

author: jantrit
content:
I’m going  fail to properly put this into words but the ability to extrapolate and have an understanding of the learning process/ be driven to take that journey. One example would be this, someone comes in fresh expecting you to spoon feed them the knowledge, that’s not super helpful. But someone comes in and can say, “oh that’s a Patchbay, can you show me how it works”. You can teach those people anything. The desire and hunger to learn on their own and the ability to acquire knowledge for themselves has been a huge divide I’ve noticed in the intern/ college community.  

One time we were setting up a session and I was explaining to our intern my thoughts about which headphones we’d give to each station. (This pair has better bass, we’ll give them to the bass player. These are open back we’ll give them to the horn section so they can blend better) The very next session without having to mention it, she had placed the same headphones in the same places AND ALSO she then took that info and made a the judgement that we’d give the nicest most comfy pair to the vocalist. That’s what I mean about extrapolation.

author: BatMeckley
content:
So, statistically this gig is one of the hardest ways to make a living in todays economy. If the kid doesn’t want it bad enough to have an initial “fuck you, I can’t imagine doing anything else this is MY LIFE” response, they’re simply not cut out for today’s realities. Too many people leading too shitty of a life because a family member gave them the “you can do it!” speech because you’re “supposed to be supportive of family even without cause”. It’s like sending them off to war with a tennis racket, and to me that’s ultimately cruel. 

So the next step is on the kid. If they come back 6 months later and are like “hey I know you said not to, but i hit YouTube and figured some stuff out and here’s 30 tracks I got here that someone other than my mom or girlfriend says is pretty cool” THEN I’m all in, and matching their effort, and providing them every opportunity to grow and succeed. But if you need constant validation you’re doing the right thing, and you can’t fight through the first (or tenth) wave of people telling you not to do this, you REALLY don’t belong in this game. It’s way too much work for way too little reward unless the work IS the reward.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
You might be right. There's quite a bit of unknowns though. The content flood of the last few years/ decade has not made as much catalog music as there used to be. So in that way, pre-internet pop culture is undervalued. We see this with iconic brands and reboots dominating Hollywood, non-hip hop samples and interpolations taking a bigger slice of pop music. 

Rod sold pub, records, and likeness. Irving Azoff has not made a lot of bad decions, historically. I also wouldn't be so confident in making calculations based on a few press release numbers. Catalog deals of this kind are incredibly complicated and have so much nuance. Like, does a $1mil record deal mean something? Yeah, but to make any judgement about it, you'd need a lot more detail. Catalog deals are much more complicated than a record deal.

Like I said, you might be right. But many good counterpoints too. Very interesting times. I definitely enjoyed reading your thoughts.

author: peterlabberton

As any observer of my occasional rants could guess, I am far more predisposed to wade carefully into the latest and greatest—most things don’t last, many just aren’t interesting to me, and those that are either interesting or necessary, I can learn quick enough usually to be fine. But I also feel strongly that this whole pursuit of doing music full time and getting paid for it needs to be pretty much entirely on my terms—if I’m gonna do it in a way I don’t like, I should just go get another career since doing *this* in a way that isn’t interesting to me is just a poorly paid way to be unhappy.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I love this.

I worked with a young artist recently. I asked him if he'd done his vocal warm-ups before he came in to cut vocals. He said "oh I forgot to do them." I asked him if he does them every day and he said "oh sometimes I forget."

I said "do you think professional athletes forget to stretch and warm-up?"

I told him if he thinks of it like homework, he won't be successful. But if he wakes up every day and says "I am a singer, this is who I am, of course this is what I do every day," then he's got a shot.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
@spectrummasters 

No surprise Ross with an extremely thoughtful post and approach, and you always with a very thoughtful initial question.

Gonna keep this as short as possible since it’s late, and I guess I’d sorta like to ruffle a few feathers lovingly. 

But from the freelance/work for hire side that I’m on, and most of us here are, I have to say, most people out here doing the thing are getting paid their ACTUAL value. 

Yet everyone thinks they are worth more. Why? Who cares that we work hard? Not the market. We make art that is totally non-essential to how society operates…for most of the projects we touch there is almost no demand and they will make very little money. Of course this doesn’t mean they are not important, I deeply think they are, but we are talking financial value here.

We need to either provide people with an amazing experience (in many ways) that they find valuable or help them earn more money. Ideally both

If you are undeniable and continue helping people earn more, feel more, be more, create more…the money cannot help but follow. And the market will tell you your value whether you like it or not

I don’t say this with the experience that others do, I have a long long way to go. so know that and of course take into account my perspective. This is all from a very loving place!

author: Chris Doms
content:
I think what’s holding me back in the music making life right now is school and my own lack of experience in the business. The time commitment in and out of the classroom between 6 classes makes it almost impossible for me to be able to adhere to anyone else’s schedules, whether that be as a freelancer or assistant. I like to think a smart trusted friend would agree but I’d also wanna know if there’s anything else they’re seeing. 

I wanna use my time in school to give back this year. Even though I can’t do music full time I’ve been freelancing. While I wanna scale up after school, a lot of the people I’ve worked with are coming back now because they feel they can’t go to another engineer where we’re at and 
get the same quality/experience they’re getting from me, and they can’t afford to go to bigger studios/engineers either. I’ve also had a lot of people make comments about how much they like my rooms vs other studios they’ve worked in. 

So while I’m in school I wanna offer my rooms to other people who are serious about their music so they can take their stuff to a level they’re happy with and is pro sounding enough. It really bums me out when I see people in the local scene who are super good, passionate, and hardworking when it comes to creating their music met with roadblocks caused by bad rooms, poor engineering, and economics. 

If anyone wants to chime in with ideas, I’m thinking of offering a free session to students at my university to come record with me/just letting friends I trust into my spaces to use while I’m in class or whatever

author: Rollmottle
content: I manage a team of younger folks in my day job and there are a ton of parallels with music. One of things that frustrates me to no end is the belief that there's a "How to" checklist for how to get good. The answer is there is no answer and it looks different for everybody. I can certainly tell you the principles and strategies for how you might get good. But you need to find your own way and do the work. And sometimes that is quite literally grinding until you break through. People don't like hearing that there really is no answer (and they think you're being a dick for telling them there isn't one...which is a whole other thing). I think the ubiquitous accessibility of information has trained a generation to expect answers to be a Google or one weird trick away.

author: Slow Hand
content:
There's an old group of avant garde European intellectuals (Situationist International) who really dug into the idea of unstructured urban exploration - what they call a *dérive*. 

It can involve walking *through* buildings, up stairs, knocking on doors, following scents and aromas, following sound, talking to people, picking a psychological concept and using that as your guiding principle. The objective is disorientation and shaking yourself out of your usual ways of engaging with your environment.

It can be a *lot* of fun to do with friends who are down for an adventure. Just step out your front door and start asking questions and following your nose.

author: LAPhill
content:
With any passion that becomes a career, a certain amount of the mystique is bound to wear off once you become one of the magic makers. To use your analogy, dating a new girl feels different than a year in, vs. being married, vs. having a family. It's absolutely normal for the type of love you have for music to evolve over time and repetition.

I kind of doubt that earning money from music is the root cause of your feelings. But it might be affecting how you encounter music. If it's all feeling too ordinary, then break the ordinary. Go listen to live music that's far away from anything you touch. Pick up an instrument you don't know how to play and get in a room with some friends and enjoy being bad, but exploring music like a child. 

The "quitting" thing often feels like something often born out of rough working experiences, or perhaps just too mundane. Bills have to get paid (burgers gotta get flipped) but perhaps you can balance those gigs with things that challenge and excite you, even if they're not particularly lucrative. 

tl;dr I think we all go through phases of questioning if the career is worth it, if not questioning our relationship with music itself, but in my experience, almost everyone comes out the other side after a bit of a mental reset.
