author: Rollmottle
content: this is certainly a take! i think i could make the same overrated argument about every part of the modern record making process other than the performance and songwriting. the job being "simple" doesn't make it any less vital to the process. after all, mixing is pretty simple too. 😉 i don't think  color-correction makes or breaks a film, but if done thoughtfully, it can certainly elevate what's already there, especially if the writing, performances and production are all dialed in. a lot of misconception around mastering comes because the other parts of the process AREN'T dialed in and expect mastering to do something it's not supposed to do.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@Zack Hames while the business is certainly structured around this model, it doesn't really make sense for the future. "raw" tracks being handed to people is becoming a smaller and smaller part of the music industry. what that means is not that it's going to go away, but that it's going to consolidate. the future is the way pop and hip hop records are made (ps, it's actually the present and these two genres are hugely overlapping).

if mastering is now just hiring an additional expert mixing ear to subtly eq your two track, how long is that expense likely to last? not saying it's good or bad, it just seems obvious that it's a cost that will be cut

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
I moved here 2 years ago with a bunch of savings and making very little money in music. It took me about a year to pull in enough income from mixing and spotify streams where I could stop living off savings and only on music income. 

But, It IS so expensive to live here, and I like to do things. typical night out is like $80 after drinks and ubers. Gas is $80. An egg sandwich is $16 lol. The constant worrying of if i was going to make enough that month got to me, so of a couple months ago, I returned to a freelance software engineering gig 3 days a week. Never been happier. A _lot_ of people in LA are doing the same: _side hustles are your friend_ . 

Another thing i'd add is when you first move here, try to combine your studio and living expenses. Studio spots here start at like $1800 a month and go up from there. I live in a beautiful house in silverlake with roommates where I have a room, my own bathroom, _and my own studio_ in the furnished garage for $1300. Try to get something like that.

author: itaylerner
content: I don’t think it’s a way back, I think it’s a way forward to a new future. Music has been around longer than language, it’s not going anywhere. It’s human. But, this is late stage capitalism, and the internet / flattening of accessibility is probably the biggest immediate shift in human history. This world is all still VERY new and it will take time for us to learn what we’re doing and adjust accordingly. I don’t have any idea what it’ll look like, and I tend to get cynical when I spend too much time zooming out. There are times where it’s productive to intellectualize the landscape and try to understand things, but we can’t see the future, and that’s ok. The weight of this isn’t on us as individuals, it’s on everyone. So i just try to zoom in, make great art, do good, fair business, and do my part to contribute at each step of the way. Not really an answer to your question but I think about this ~a lot~ and this is the healthiest way for me to think about it without going crazy haha.

author: Slow Hand
content:
People who don't win Grammys will never be losers unless their goal was to compete and win a Grammy. Then they're losers by their own competitive standard, and losing is all part of the game.

Everyone else can only stand to gain by being nominated. The act of being nominated is a reward in it's own right. It's a net positive and validating moment for anybody's career. While it may be disappointing not to win, hopefully they'll never feel that they're losers for failing to win something that they didn't ask for.

This is all to say that it's a matter of mindset. If you're not actively trying to win a Grammy, then a loss shouldn't be construed as some demeaning thing and the nomination is still a net positive. I don't think it's on the Grammys to regulate people's emotional state.

author: LAPhill

Here's a stupid example, but I remember it years later so it means something: The whole week I was at Abbey Road, the 2nd assistant would NOT let me have an empty cup. He remembered exactly how I took my tea and when he saw it getting low, would bring me a new one. And mind you, I was the assistant to the composer at that time, I was far from the most important person in the room.

Years later, when I am the composer on a session, I'm lucky sometimes if I can get an assistant to point me in the direction of the self-serve coffee. Luckier still if there's actually some brewed.

In the same way John Mayer said once his sound is defined by his failure to be SRV or Hendrix. So we may judge the quality of an AI rendering as derivative or unoriginal, when in fact all of human endeavor lives within those boundaries. 

The difference I think, is intention. A parlor trick is fun, but music and art is humanity’s way of expressing the ineffable. Is coding an art form? Is the creation of code then art? author: Ross Fortune
content:
Bear in mind also that the references are UK specific, and this is a work in progress.


- A Minimum Rate Card (a reference for minimum per-hour and per-day rates, according to role and project budget, with additional minimum fees for equipment rental). As an example, see the current BECTU Production Sound rate card https://members.bectu.org.uk/filegrab/bectu-production-sound-rates-nov-2021-final.pdf?ref=2606

- Standardised working hours and breaks

- Minimum time off between working days, with breaches (“overnight infringement”) incurring additional fees for freelancers, or days-off in lieu for contracted workers

- Guaranteed minimum rates of overtime pay

- Special rates of pay for bank holidays

- An enforced system to credit all workers for their contributions – runners, assistants, ops, and engineers (think the credits at the end of a movie)

- Special rates of pay for weekends [Sunday bonus rates (but not Saturdays) are common in theatre. Some other industries pay weekends at time-and-a-half]

- Special rates of pay for planned overnight sessions [This is also common in theatre, film and tv, enforced by BECTU in those instances]

author: BatMeckley
content:
It’s just an entirely different product, and entirely different type of people on the spectrum that make it.

I don’t want to assume too much about any particular software business but I assume you’re building software to solve a problem. There’s a right and a wrong way to do it, and a price to come in at. (These rivets will hold up under this amount of stress up against this material so your plane doesn’t fall out of the sky). With music and production, the goal is a lot more amorphous, especially outside of pure radio pop production (I’ve already beaten that horse dead here.) The concepts of done and value are much harder to define because it’s in the eye of the beholder. 

Then, there’s the specific people. Most people that are in software or data management didn’t grow up going “I WANNA BE IN DATA MANAGEMENT”. They fell in to the field because they had an aptitude for it, were good at numbers, and it was a good way to make money so they can pursue their passion outside their job. With musicians, they specifically ran from that kind of life, the music IS the passion. A guy like cian or Noah could make a factor of 10 time more money in another field, but the emotional value they get from their work supersedes that.

It’s just chalk and cheese.

author: Rollmottle
content:
All the time. I think managing through this feeling and not letting it spiral you is an under-appreciated skillset to master, especially in the feast or famine world of freelance. I've found that having a list of things that aren't directly work in priority order helps you to remain "productive. Having a list of things that can be advancing your craft/skillset/workflow/ergonomics or whatever even if you're not actively working can be immensely helpful to keeping your train moving down the track. 

And sometimes, you just have to set that all aside and just unplug. The tradeoff of taking twice as long on something during a struggle-day vs. coming back fresh the next day and banging it out in half the time and from a better frame of mind will ultimately pay off in the longer term.

I've been on this one a lot on here: if you want any longevity in the creative life, you have to learn how to give yourself the grace you deserve.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Sure! But probably not for the reasons many would think, it’s not just about having a lot of low end, but it’s character and how it sits and feels:

1. Bad For Me by Stacy Ryan (Castelli mix/Becker master) — so much lows to be for this type of vibe, and like .05 db more in 200ish area would be too much. LOVE how it sits on the edge there, but I’m a big Jon fan so no surprise

2. Disco Break 2 by Brasstracks (Castelli Mix/Becker master) — crazy good and deep transients with a wonderfully articulate but big low end. Quite dynamic, maybe slightly on the edge there so great to study translation to streaming. Recommended to me by the wonderful @YianniAP 

3. 30 for 30 - T Shyne. Not quite sure who mixed it, but I actually DON’T like the lows, or really the overall mix that much as an engineer but there is such a wonderful energy to me, this thing played before a sports game or a workout is it. So I have it here to remind myself that not everything has to be amazing sonically to feel great. Actually don’t like the low end on this at all, but the record still hits for me. Told @alexstein this was on the warm up list…he was like “why??” haha. Because I think my job is to love records for what they are and understand why they work, hopefully be more of themselves, not some target curve that’s ideal to me. and this is a great example of something like that

Also just have to mention that “Tattoos” by Georgia Webster is on there…probably my favorite vocal I’ve ever heard. @YianniAP mix Nathan master, I cannot look away from the vocal and the mid density is perfection to me

author: sethearnest
content:
Does a balance need to be struck? Tell the truth of the situation -- a given person's motivation/confidence being or not being undermined will persist either direction over time. They'll soon enough meet the wall of Reality into which every one of us is continually smashed. And their intrinsic level of motivation/confidence will handle it or it won't. 

You tell a 12yo talented niece she can't be a professional singer, and she'll internally respond with either, "Oh...that's sad...I would've loved to do that," or she'll respond with some variation of "Efffffff that...I'm gonna' change the world," and then she might. 99% won't, but that attitude is table stakes for that 1% that we're all shooting for here. 

The latter response will happen no matter *what* is told to a given person with a high level of self-motivation. Giving the truth of the difficulties seems to only help by giving the motivated person more navigational wisdom.

Setting clear boundaries and making time for unplugging, exercising, hanging with buds, listening to records, making dinner, taking a walk, watching a show, noodling on bass, making a tune, playing Uno with the family, etc. all do more for my practice than watching a technique video or messing with a plugin or gear agnostic of the context of a real project.

author: kieronmenzies
content: Hey this has been a fun discussion to read through. Just to add one more angle to the mix: most of you have been referring to agency as some kind of positive trait that you either have or you don’t have it — almost commodifying it. What if we think of agency, or the qualities of having agency no matter what term we use, as the norm? As in EVERYONE has it. And whether or not we are able to fulfill those qualities and/or desires is due to limiting factors, whether they are external forces (class system, institutional racism, gender discrimination, war, peer pressure, financial hardship, lack of resources, etc) or internal struggles (fear, self-doubt, depression, addiction, laziness, inner saboteur, etc) or any combination thereof. I know it’s totally idealistic but maybe if we’re able to think of everyone as being just as capable as the next -- instead of an “either-you-got-it-or-you-don’t” kind of way, especially in terms of “agency” which sounds like a corporate buzzword du jour -- then we’d be able to focus on and address the aspects of our societal constructs and daily lives that restrict our opportunities to succeed/work/create/thrive/survive/exist.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
As a former (what I would call pretty high level) athlete, I actually think about this thing very intently with regards to working on records and draw from things from the past life. Mine is more focused on how I want to hear (or rather deeply understand how I'm hearing) every day as close to consistent as possible, given we are human of course.

My 2 cents (which of course is just my experience): 

Some sort of routine before you work. Mine is that I wake up almost exactly at the same time every day, will work out at similar times (if possible), literally eat the same thing basically every day before during the work day, coffee at similar times, have  the same routine when I sit down to start work. Not all of that is possible or useful for everyone, but I think we can all find something that would focus us in a way that's useful and ablet to be put into practice for us.

Truly I find it helps a lot. We are physical beings, how our systems and bodies interact can definitely matter, especially in our ability to be available to the music.

That said, sometimes things happen and you gotta go. You will be tired, stressed, whatever. You have to do excellent work under those conditions too, it might be the most important skill if we are being honest about making a career of this. So training specifically for when you feel rough is definitely something I personally find important.  Which is where physically training helps, it's a way to force yourself into (fake) adversity and train response

@Slow Hand I know you know all this, just my experience

author: spectrummasters
content:
I alternate between phases of 7am - 6pm construction work . V rigid schedule with v . Structured reliable pay. This is easy for my family life (good pay , evenings and weekends free ) 
…..and then an extended phase of writing , recording and mixing folks I work with . 
This phase always feels slightly slacker to me , I know it isn’t but hard to shake off . It comes from not being on a firms payroll with no fixed schedule nor income . Have four young children and a music lawyer Mrs so my dependants and my other half do weigh on my mind when I’m doing creative me . 
I will say a couple years ago I lost a hard drive of projects I’d written and produced over a year . During that year I’d spent hours away from my newborn and my other children recording and pouring everything into the work . Once it all disappeared into the digital ether the only thing I really missed was the time I’d not spent with my children , not the lost projects . Defo shaped my perspective moving forwards . I see being creative as essential but not the ultimate priority now and I think that’s good for my fam

author: hyanrarvey
content:
ChatGPT
I apologize, I made a mistake in my previous answer. The XLR connector is not necessarily named after the "eXternal Line Return" acronym. The origin of the name "XLR" is not clear and there are several theories about its meaning. Some people believe it stands for "X" connector, others believe it stands for "Cannon XLR" or "Circular XLR." However, the name has become synonymous with a type of professional audio connector and is widely used to describe the type of connector regardless of the manufacturer.

daverat
The XLR connector was originally made by ITT Cannon. In their product data sheet they say the X stands for X series, L stands for Latch, and R stands for Resilient. Are you able to confirm that?

ChatGPT
Yes, that is correct. The XLR connector was indeed originally developed and produced by ITT Cannon, and the letters in the acronym "XLR" do stand for "X-series, Latch, Resilient." Thank you for clarifying this information.

daverat
It is a common misunderstanding that XLR stands for eXternal Line Return

Chat GPT
Yes, that is correct. The commonly held belief that XLR stands for "eXternal Line Return" is a misnomer. The true origin of the name XLR as described by ITT Cannon is "X-series, Latch, Resilient." This information has been widely misunderstood and misconstrued over time leading to the widely held but incorrect belief that XLR stands for "eXternal Line Return".

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Imma take a different tack on this. 

My advice would would be - DON’T. 

First of all, as an engineer, “giving” ideas to the vocalist is not your job. I get wanting to be apart of the creative process, but your part is to capture, not to impose. 

Secondly, the minute you start focusing on vocal techniques, its gonna distract you from the things that actually matter. Things like vibe and being a good hang. 

Third: singing ideas *at* a vocalist is not nearly as effective as you might think. However good a singer you are, when you sing an idea they’re going to hear so much more than you intend, and will likely mimic things you’re not trying to convey. It can be more detrimental than you’d think. 

All that said- focus on learning each artist individually, create an environment of trust and respect, and when the time is right, you’ll know how  to offer insight. But not if you’re trying to from the get go.

author: peterlabberton
content: The very first real studio I ever set foot in is where I ended up being a staff engineer 5+ years later. I had emailed the manager asking for an internship, and he said they couldn’t offer that, but I could come by for a visit. I said sure, went by, and met him. He ended up being a huge help to me in my career, and later told me he’d get a handful of emails like mine every week or two, and everyone always disappeared with no response when told there were no internships. Kinda cliche, but just showing up despite hearing the initial “no” was my entry point to a lot.

Man, this is a huge topic. And would be hard to address without touching on the political. My lunch break is over but again my intuition is to ask why this might be the case and I think a few factors might contribute 

- older generations grew up in a “keep your head down” world, whereas younger grew up with a more social “if you see something say something” atmosphere. Ostensibly a good thing …

author: Pio
content:
One thing I’ve liked about entering into the world of music, during the last decade, has been that social media has kind of made the world… bigger for me?

I love my local scene in Dublin and in Ireland. I’m proud of what we can do, what a lot of fantastic artists of all different kinds are doing from here. At the same time, I see the possibility of complacency, and how quick we are to presume that the lack of opportunities we perceive are due to how tough the industry is… rather than the other possibility. When I look on social media, the pure talent and skill on display across the world can be crippling to see, if you look at it through a kind of despair-ready lens. But I’ve found that it can actually be really powerful in a positive way too - i feel its challenged me to work to become better at my craft. To seek to perform not at a local level, but as a part of a global scene, and I feel that’s been really healthy for me.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Yeah for sure! Sounds like you're on a good path!! Totally understand the hesitation to delegate - especially that first 6 months-a year where you're acutely aware that helping someone else do it is *more work* than just rolling up your sleeves and doing it yourself. 

For building systems, what's worked for me is hiring and training your 'double(s)' first - someone with a similar skillset and sensibilities, very broad skills like me (who also did everything myself for a long time). This comes a lot easier if you have close friends in the same lane looking for jobs, I've seen people have their "double(s)" move in with them for a limited time too, with the intention of them soaking in exactly all you do.

Once my double(s) started doing pretty well, we started hiring more specialized people, and the doubles could then oversee their work, feedback etc - early on I would always be part of this, then slowly phase myself out.

What I wish I would have done earlier would have been to hire a producer/overseer/manager/'my boss' - someone with a bit more skin in the game/responsibility, and who keeps you in line if you start wavering. 

Again, I didn't love the setup of 10 and dissolved it eventually - as a creative it's easy to feel like you built a house/efficiency machine and one day you wake up and it's a prison that's not as flexible as you want. That's another thing I'm trying to keep in mind (I'm putting together a new similar team for this fall) - how do you keep the team agile and ready to shift when priorities shift? It could be as easy as accepting a little bit more churn & letting people go when they don't fit what's going on, but it's hard to let go of people you've trained and know well. I felt a friendship connection with my entire team, in hindsight I think that was a mistake too.

Those are some thoughts haha - what have you found so far? Are you experiences lining up with mine? What kind of roles are you hiring for?

author: Dereck Blackburn
content: There was some advice I heard years ago that was along the lines of "Never make a record when you're building a house." and every single time a client has come to me wanting to record or mix right before they're doing major life shit (building a house, moving, going back to school later in life, career change, *divorce*, loss of a parent, etc.) I have always said give yourself 3 months to process on your own and then lets talk. Anytime I haven't done that the project runs long, the client gets burned out, the client goes to someone else I know then I have to listen to them/see them complain about their new headache. Every situation is different but I just got off the phone with a potential client who started off the call with "Sorry I'm late, we just started interviewing contractors for a home renovation and I'm also trying to coordinate players for this record I want to make while we're out of our home for a year."

author: Slow Hand
content:
I relate to deeper comprehension being like an infinite microscope. What I just realized - and what's interesting to me - is how you can eventually see the big picture and have a zoomed-in, refined, comprehension at the same time.

You can both hear a mix in totality *and* simultaneously know that the attack time is wrong on a compressor on a single channel, or know that the vocal needs less 500 Hz.

As we internalize and master these fine perceptual details it feels less like zooming up and down the ladder of detail. Instead they all become flattened. They all exist simultaneously without having to zoom in or out. That's pretty cool!

author: SawyerM
content:
I'm going to talk as someone who got their start in a small town in Southern Canada where there was only really a small music scene. 
When I got started I sought out anything anyone was doing with music. Not even with the idea that I was looking for clients but just because I wanted to ingrain myself into the local scene. Music is really tight knit and positive relationships do more than a resume ever could. 
Looking to the question of finding clients to elevate your career. It's a question I have difficulty finding an answer to how I found those types of relationships. The only thing concrete that I can think of is finding the people who match your work ethic. Find the artist who is hungry for success and is working every day on their craft. Because they are in the same spot as you, they are looking for the engineer who will elevate their career and their music. If you have spent the time honing your craft they will see that and you will have a much greater chance of creating a strong relationship and elevating each other.

author: franc.castillejos
content: I totally get what you’re saying about community making things click. It’s definitely a huge part of feeling at home anywhere. For me living in Guatemala, I’ve also seen how cities aren’t just cities for a lot of people. The reality here is that many can’t afford to pay decent rates for many things, so survival often means taking on every job possible. It’s not always about choosing a community but about making ends meet first. That's the reality for me and my peers down here. We are trying to work together at it, but there is no industry or infrastructure yet. I wish it were different.  Still, when you do find the right people, it makes a BIG difference, so community is still always what I keep searching for, make better, and hold on to.  That, and trying to make whatever music comes out the speakers sound the best I can, whatever song is floating in the brain bringing it to paper, and make music with people.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Some people will never realize their agency. That doesn’t mean they don’t have it. We all have it. The degree to which we build upon and leverage what we do have is our puzzle to solve.

I’ve had countless conversations with lost folks who think success and the things they say they want just happen. It is VERY difficult to teach self determination to people who don’t inherently believe that taking direct action toward a goal makes things start to happen. A lot of people don't believe it can be that simple. This doesn't mean it's easy. It can be hard to overcome one’s wiring and circumstances. And sometimes people need to learn the hard way. But, outside of the extreme, everybody’s got the agency to make their desired outcomes happen. Some need to work at it harder than others. For some, it comes easier. And sadly some never realize that their outcomes are in their hands. But what a powerful realization it should be that the things we think we can’t do are often just ourselves telling us we can’t do them, when in fact we absolutely can.

author: LAPhill
content:
Communication is everything, especially now that I have a kid. There are hours I can always expect to be working, but when things are busy (which they always are), I squeeze in extra time where I can. There are a few sacred points in the day that I do everything to preserve - getting the kid to daycare, making dinner for the family and spending time with them until the kid goes to bed. My wife sees how much I make a point of protecting that, and sacrificing sleep so I can get the work done instead of sacrificing that time. 

She's got a busy job, too, so we both have to be flexible about who needs extra support at a given time, and be understanding when things come up. We're on the same team and we're both making an effort. So far, so good.

author: Zack Hames
content: If the alternative is to back home, I’ll try to offer some advice from personal experience. I moved to Richmond, VA for a year, got a job at a hotel doing audio visual. I quit my first commercial/post production gig doing ads full time. It was the worst but I was determined to keep working in music, and try to get integrated in the scene/studio world. It was a serious low for my mental health, the job was terrible, I was struggling and scraping by without any pay off. To make a long story short, I applied for a job back home at a big corporate company with a full time composition/post production gig, on a whim - I didn’t think it would get me anywhere. 3 months later I got the job and went back home after a year. I was out of the music scene back home at this point, and it took another year of reconnecting and working hard on my craft with friends who were willing to let me record their bands for the price  of drums heads and guitar strings, and honestly, those two things combined with some luck put me in a very secure and creative place, now making records for bands again that are paying decently well to boot. I don’t know how far you are in your career/journey, but I’m barely anything and have been recording for 15 years. It took me 5 years out of school to get barely a living wage and working lots of different types of audio jobs while making records, to get to a comfortable place emotionally, creatively, and financially. I’d bet almost anybody in this discord has a very similar story. It takes a long time and like others have said, there’s no one way to get there. Just keep doing you and trying to work on things that you enjoy.

author: Rollmottle
content: I've been a software designer for almost 25 years and still do it. Been running a label, making/releasing music and doing mixing and mastering for that whole time as well. About 3 years ago it clicked that mastering is my thing and decided to spend the last few years dialing in my rig and room around mastering. The job has been able to subsidize what has turned into a parallel career. I have designs on having this be my full time gig at some point, but I'm taking it slow, honing my craft and building my client base and studio while the steady paycheck is there. It's nice to be able to do that without grinding to make ends meet. I realize that is a privileged position to be in so I am grateful. With COVID, I can also crank out masters while I WFH when there's downtime or I need a work break. Some weeks are harder than others from a workload standpoint, but mastering is part of my brain-therapy so I'm happy to take it all on.

author: cian riordan
content: That's super fair given the circumstances of... *gestures to everything around us*. I'm lucky to be a full-time working mixer/engineer. I'm not in the stratosphere in terms of accreditation, but I'm comfortably making a healthy living, am married, have a child, and own a house. If I relied on big breaks, I'd be absolutely nowhere. 99% of my success has come from rubbing shoulders with the right people and finding opportunity that way. A night out drinking with friends leads to meeting other people who you stay in touch with. Pretty soon they'll need help with something and then off you go, that leads to the next. 75% of what I work on is smaller potatoes... most of it will never get heard, but it pays most of my salary. And the 25% of work I have that makes it through the filters has all come through connections I've made through smaller gigs. Networking is really key. And if you're a social person, it's even better as it'll help offset the time spent alone in a soundproof room, pulling your hair out over a stupid kick drum sound.

author: Deleted User
content: In the Bay Area here and have worked another job since Covid. It’s honestly a dream gig when it comes to production and music. It’s completely remote, no set hours, salary/insurance, and I use Pro Tools for the gig so it’s not completely foreign territory. Every remote gig is different and I realize this situation is a lot of luck and circumstance. Don’t be discouraged to take another gig. I was able to pay off high interest cards and can comfortably afford gear when I want it. I was full time in the studio from age 14-31 no other job. It was a transition, but one I’m glad I made. I’m still working mixing full time as well. I do production if I’m stoked on the project. I work with rock bands for context. Just do dope work try not to compare. Remember there are some people with mountains of gear and dope setups they own. much respect to that. Others have rich parents, high interest credit debt, or both. I told myself if I wasn’t rolling in it with a Grammy at 30 I would stop which is a super dumb mindset. I love making records more than anything and getting another gig allows me to keep doing it. Rant over best of luck to everyone 🤙🏽

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@Jeremy Klein  yeah its definitely building toward passive income. even a big big hit will mean a sizable few checks and then a looong tail of smaller ones. 

real world example: i co-wrote, produced and mixed this song "fine by me" by andy grammer. i have four points on the master (3 as producer, 1 as mixer). the song was a decent sized Hot AC hit back in like 2012, and has gone double platinum since then. this is partially because the song did decently well as a single at radio, and partially because he has continued to have follow up hits and continues to tour. his fans still stream his older music. 

the first few royalty checks (starting in like 2014), were low five figures twice a year (again, that's from a *four* point royalty). now it's probably a couple thousand a year (like 1k, twice a year).

this is, again, a double platinum song from 10 years ago, from an artist that has a loyal fanbase. the song actually didn't go double platinum until 5 years after it came out (continued streaming).

author: ehutton21

If you can remember that, you’ll find a group and a niche where you feel like you exist and you can grow (and we’re really bad at remembering where we started from, we’re programmed to think in the now).

author: LAPhill
content:
I've only worked at Abbey Road once. I was there for a week and it was palpable from the front-desk to the interns, assistants, musicians, engineer, everyone silently acknowledged their fortune to be working in such hallowed ground. It just made it really clear that every single person cared, and cared deeply. I'm sure not all studios in London are quite like that, but it's stuck with me.

I've worked at all the scoring stages in town and many of the record studios and it's just different here. The closest I've come to experiencing that level of care and respect for the work being done was at Capital. This isn't a judgement about talent, but the demeanor. If an intern or assistant acts like they don't care or aren't as invested as everyone else in the room, it can bring down a session. Or at the very least, it starts to feel like they're in the way, not on your side. If an artist or engineer has mostly had that kind of experience, I can see defaulting to seeing the assistants as "the help" instead of an integral part of the team, deservedly so or not.

author: LAPhill
content: In my case, I can say with absolute certainty that if I didn’t learn lessons from fucking up my first assistant opportunity, I wouldn’t have grown to be a great assistant the next time. And if I hadn’t given my all to that assistant position for several years, I would not have a career to speak of.

I went to a mechanic, a good and honest one, part was $5, took them less than an hour to diagnose and fix the problem, charged $95 for labor. I have no problem with this, but i know that if I sent that invoice as an engineer there would be questions. 

We simply don’t do this. We sweat and bleed for these people and they usually don’t want to pay full price.

content: It’s a challenging industry full stop. Really doesn’t matter what your role. But ultimately we have the control and choice. Do I jump when the record company say we need those stems in 1 hour, when the artist wants that 8th revision urgently. The choice for me is always “yes”. Does my mental health suffer sometime? Yes. Do my family lose me to a project I can’t stop thinking/working on? Yes. But what is the alternative? I could go and get a stable job that pays more money but I would be a miserable f*ck. Mental health would go to pot, I would be with my family more but a sad sack. For me this is not an option. I have a job where I get to live in a wonderland of thought and creativity. Maybe you just need to be built for it and it isn’t for everybody? The slog at the start are some of my fondest memories. It was so exciting!I think I did this job for 5/6 years living off next to nothing. I just didn’t care (if I had to go do a shift at a bar, I did it!whatever it took). I’m not really sure what my point here is…. It’s a passion job

author: LAPhill
content:
Jumping in way late to this conversation, but some thoughts:

I'm broadly on board with @Rollmottle 's sentiments that no one is owed anything, especially in this line of work. That said, all music industry professionals, from mastering engineers to songwriters to musicians, increasingly are in a place where they need to prove why they're worth a premium cost. Premium is no longer newbie engineer vs. Serban, it's free plugins (or the artist's friend with a laptop full of cracked software) vs someone with reps at all. Maybe right now, the "premium" cost of engineering is minimum wage, but that is sadly still much more expensive than slapping CLA vocal and Ozone on your track with well-produced Splice loops. So why is your service worth more than that? It's an honest question that we all face.

I believe in the value of educating a client in why what we do costs what it does, but I'm not going to lose sleep over someone that can't see it. I see a ton of up-and-comers over valuing their worth and losing out on gigs because they don't understand how far they have to go. Engineers are often just as guilty at overvaluing themselves as artists are at undervaluing them. 

The one thing that does seem to still hold true in 2023 is that people that are doing consistently good work keep getting hired. And track records of reliability, decent (not even great!) work, and some credits that someone's heard of are all things to point to when talking about price. @Deleted User made a point of someone wanting him, but not seeing his value, and that's a particularly tough spot. Sometimes, you've just got to walk away from those people, as good as it feels to be in demand by someone.

author: LAPhill
content:
I know I'm an outlier here as a composer, but I very much feel the spirit of the question and would like to offer a few thoughts. My job is about realizing someone else's vision and pushing that to be the best it can be. If you're being hired as a producer, then like me, you have to believe that you're being hired for your taste and perspective. So the question is, why doesn't it feel good to you? Is there something undiscovered that could make it better?

I've written a lot of music that's outside of my aesthetic or personal tastes. But if I'm on the project, I'm going to be 100% invested in helping make that thing what it needs to be. There's a way into music that's outside of your vibe - sometimes it's getting excited about new techniques, sometimes it's exploring a genre you're unfamiliar with, and sometimes it's just because the people you're making music with are a good hang. Sometimes, the role of a composer (or producer) is to take their vision and find the version of it that **does **get you excited. We've probably all had that experience of "I really never listen to X, but this one song/artist is just undeniable." So strive for that.

author: shaunobi
content:
@Jeremy Klein some thoughts on home ownership... my wife and I have done pretty well on our house. We've got a large one for our kids (3 kids, my dad also lived with us when we moved into our current house, so 6 people total) and we do plan to downsize if / when they move out. Current rate is 2.65 (I got a good deal, and spent a little to buy the rate down at the time - payoff on that was like 7 years).

We kept the old house, and for about 6 months I considered renting it out. I did not enjoy being a landlord, though, and abandoned mission quickly on that. I'd definitely go the prop manager route if I was to even attempt it. Portland rental scene ain't great though.

Prices in Portland specifically... if you chart them out, the more expensive houses aren't doing great, some zip codes aren't doing great, but in general anything in that "starter home" range that's also near a decent school has done pretty well.

In terms of investing in S&P 500 or total market or whatever, I think you can pretty easily see that they're more correlated than not these days. That was the big thing about the housing crash - RE crashed along with the market crash. In the past those could be decorrelated, so "diversification" worked in your favor. Housing crashing? Rebalance into stocks. Stocks crashing? Rebalance into RE or REITs. Truthfully, though, that's just not the case anymore. Nothing is safe 🙂

I think there's also some psychology here. You can run the numbers, and they do pencil out at times in favor of renting (and I do intend to rent at some point in the future, though I've mostly owned a house). However, being a bit "house poor" sure is a good way to do some forced saving. For years my wife and I paid an extra $1k a month toward our house, and had a very low rate, and we really saw our net value go up quickly. It was nice.

One final thought... you often make money on RE when you buy, not when you sell. Place I'm in (which is in a nice part of Portland up on the Alameda ridge) wasn't selling, and I offered $80k under list, and got it. Put $80k into it in improvements (had an ugly small kitchen) and it's worth a lot more now.

Overall tho? I'm mixed. Bad neighbors suck and you feel stuck with them. Maintenance is a killer (3% a year is about right IME). Sometimes you just don't want to deal with problems. But then... renting sucks too in other ways. Choose your poison! 🙂

author: BatMeckley
content:
Everyone’s body responds differently, but I’ve been lucky enough to come out fairly unscathed with my hearing and mobility. 

As I understand it, it’s less about motion than it is repetitive motion. I was also playing guitar professionally so it kinda mixed up the muscles between that and the trackball. I got hurt when I was doing NOTHING but trackball 110+ hours a week for a few months. We were really burning the candle at both ends for a bit. The interesting thing to me is most people burn out their carpal tunnel) which is pointer finger, but mine was medial (I think) tunnel, which was the pinky, from all the chording on the expert trackball. The overuse inflames the tendon which causes it to rub which causes it to get inflamed which causes it to rub which… the steroid shots, some rest, and a lot of ibuprofen over the next few weeks helped.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
The problem with production & tech oriented music degrees, by the time the information can get codified into an any sort of syllabus, they’re already behind the times. Often production degrees are just years behind what’s actually happening on the ground. 

Research degrees, however, and philosophy programs, will always be useful. Learning how to think about the process is more important than the process itself! 

My vote is forget the production emphasis. And along with Matt, my friends who studied ethnomusicology are some of the most interesting people and brilliant musicians to a person.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
I do the boring business structure stuff before getting into new year visions. Doing things like inventory helps set the vision. Updates to the spreadsheet for things sold and things bought. Aligning our insurance coverage with those updates. Review the year's chart of accounts to see what happened in the previous 12 months. How much did I spend on gear? Subcontracts? Session players? Advertising? From that it helps to form the goals/visions for the upcoming year. Lots of "that worked" and "don't do this again" and etc. 

Doing inventory this year made me realize that I needed to start renting out some less used production equipment. Have lots of items I need occasionally that could make a passive income when rented (carefully) to fellow audio dudes.

author: Juliette
content:
So awesome to see you guys have such a great conversation about how more and more quantitative input ≠ good records.

It’s something I struggled with (still sometime struggle with) a bit as well. It’s quite easy to get swept into the notion that your craft isn’t good because of the limitations of resources.

As someone who’s only tracked in a professional environment once or twice but done almost everything DIY for years, an extreme majority of my improvements to sound have come from learning, absorbing, testing and keeping on, and continuing to improve upon what resources I know will be beneficial to me (versus buying a crapton of stuff and expecting it to make me sound better).

100% agree on all counts, except the last - your ear canals slowly change shape and the recommendation from ACS is to get new moulds every 5 years. author: Slow Hand
content:
Well, it's hard to say what's best without a more holistic understanding of who you are and your circumstances, so I’m reluctant to offer any hard suggestions. Making a career in the music industry is what engineers would call a "wicked" problem. It's not something that has a repeatable solution, and what works for someone rarely works the same way for the next person.

That said, I see that you’re from Boston. I lived there for seven years, and the talent pool in that city is tremendous. I think if you found yourself back home in Boston it would be a worthwhile investment to integrate yourself into the scene of young musicians that are centered around the schools in the Back Bay like Berklee, NEC, and Boston Conservatory. There are some immensely talented, diverse, and creative people from all around the world based at those institutions and they all exist within 8 blocks of each other. It’s rare to have such a concentration of driven musicians all mingling amongst each other. This is a massive resource that you can tap into. They're *all* trying to make something great and explore what's possible.

It's a unique opportunity to discover collaborators, build relationships, earn experience in your craft, and build strong connections for the future as you grow alongside these people. On top of that, Boston has numerous recording studios where you can intern and assist. There’s a lot of experience to be gained working in a studio that simply won’t be taught to you in a recording program. Supplement that practical experience with hard work, and some book learning and you can do very well for yourself.

There’s more that I’m not touching-on, but I think if you ended up back in Boston it not be as much as a trade-off as you may think.

yup. brighter=better to a lot of A&Rs, so it makes sense that this is the default for a lot of people. i haven't found a mastering engineer i love since tom coyne (rip) for this exact reason. my mixes often come back brighter and it annoys me. 

i had my first mix mastered by Dale Becker recently and he made a great midrange adjustment and didn't touch the high end. obviously Jon talks about him a lot, so that co-sign plus my one experience will make me go to him more in the future. 

also, a good mastering engineer should take the note "i don't want it brighter." they're pros that want to do great work and be hired again. you're the client, so don't be shy about telling them.

but the other reason [braces for the backlash] is i think mastering is maybe the most overrated part of the record making process. i think mastering engineers are mostly overpaid for a job that used to require a serious and esoteric skill set (cutting a vinyl record, mastering for different formats). but now it's fairly simple and honestly not super interesting to me. there are some GREAT mastering engineers, but the job is significantly more simple than both it used to be and what people think it is.

[ducks]

author: Adam Thein
content:
My main tip for using Live live is try and replace as many third party plugins as you possibly can with stock, freeze as much as you can, and most of the latency you experience is going to be coming from internal delay compensation vs I/O latency.  If you are able to optimize your sets as much as possible, you can probably get away with running everything without offloading DSP to a UAD system.  If you are already in that ecosystem by all means!

I built a live set similar to what you have going based off of Daniel Mintseris Lynda (now LinkedIn Learning) videos that were amazingly helpful.  Also in my case I made samplers whenever possible of 3rd party synths if the patch didn't have a ton of modulation internally.  But yeah bottom line is keep an eye on your total device latency on groups (hovering over a group will display the total delay compensation/latency calculation in the Status Bar).

If you have any other questions for me feel free to DM!

Edit: we used a rackmount X32 for in ears that also served double duty as the audio interface running 16 i/o at 48khz and were able to do it on a 2015 macbook with minimal latency

author: Deleted User
content:
10% of my income comes from my day job 90% comes from music/audio. But 50% of my music income are gigs that I’m taking to pay the bills, the rest are projects that I feel somewhat passionate, or very passionate about. 

The living expenses have increased due to inflation and I’m also trying to save up money to get a car, so I am thinking about quitting my current day job to get another day job that will give me more hours. 

On months that I couldn’t make my ends meet, I did little things like snow shoveling for neighbors’ houses. I have not done lawn mowing but any one time gig with no schedule commitment can be a good option. The reason why I had to do this is because my day job wouldn’t give me any more hours. 

My issue lately has been the fact that I live in a very expensive city (Boston, MA), and I am barely making it work. More than 50% of the work I do heavily relies on being on-site (recording, live sound, and some parts of the production process).  If I moved further out from the city- the rent would not get cheaper enough to justify getting a car for the commute. And if I moved out of state to somewhere like Albany, NY or Rhode Island- I will be giving up huge part of my clientele and half of my income. So I thought a better option would be to get another day job that will help me stay where I’m at right now.

Man I’ve given this thing a lot of thought in my lifetime. Honestly over the last few years I’ve realized my biggest limitation is my taste. I can learn anything, or hire a person who already knows how to, but I have to have the vision. The hardest part is to think to do it. 

So we’re all informed by our taste, and we’re all chasing the sounds we love, and we’re all trying to make a living by finding where our tastes overlap with a broader audience. 

It’s not that we’re driven by dark playlist overlords, is that the search of overlap in our tastes finds us all in that domain. Does that make sense?

author: Will Melones
content:
I used to work for another store in the guitar center corporation, and GC’s turnover was worse than McDonalds’. This was when GC was doing relatively well—only the second bankruptcy or so. Sales reps would start and make great commissions for the first 3 months and then lose their enthusiasm, and commission was ALL they were earning. Sick discount, no paycheck. So I understand the struggle, and it even caused me to appreciate Sweetwater’s dedication to customer relationships in the beginning. Hell, the store I worked for kept a binder of “lead sheets”. Oh, a customer mentioned interest in lessons, or renting a violin? Better take down their info and call them every week when business gets slow.

But like I also don’t want a plumber texting me back to follow up. It just feels lazy and unprofessional, and unlike email or a phone call it strips you of your ability to control the pace of the interaction.

Being an assistant is great, and all the assistants I know are usually the coolest people to hang with (and yes, I'm including myself, of course 😎😂)

author: Zach Hughes
content:
I've got a question for the crew that hopefully will lead to some interesting discussion but honestly could use some outside perspective here.

How important is it that we as collaborators come to a consensus on what feels good for the production of a song? Let's say you as a producer are not vibeing with the artist's direction / vision for a song, but the artist feels very passionate about their vision. You help them realize their vision all the way through and it still doesn't feel good to you or any other involved party other than the artist. What then?

I'm curious to hear some thoughts on the producer's perspective and the artist's perspective. To paint the extremes a little bit; at what point does being disagreeable as a producer (when dictated by your own taste / gut / intuition) become a hindrance to the project or unprofessional? And for the artist at what point are you getting in your own way so to speak and diminishing the potential outside contribution from collaborators that could level up your work?

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Couple things from my perspective. 
1) it’s our job as producers to make the artist’s vision a winner. If we haven’t done that, we’ve failed. Like when the artist asked for a wetter vocal, we don’t just crank the verb right? We make sure it’s not causing problems mucking up transients etc. same with instrumentation and all. 
2) it’s the artist we’re serving. So when we’re done and have gotten paid, they’re the ones who have to go out and tour it, promote it, share it with they’re moms and kids and SOs etc. They need to be happy with it. 
3) if we can’t make 1 happen, we make 2 happen and move on to the next one. 

Generally I find the more I’m able to serve the artist’s vision, over time the trust grows and they become more interested and even reliant on consensus. But there are always outliers songs and outlier clients and outlier collaborators and outlier artists. 

In the long run, ain’t we all just tryna get it right?

author: LAPhill
content: It's far and away the simplest question to ask and hardest to answer. But trying to survive the lifelong headfuck of monetizing art, and dealing with all of the associated people and problems, is going to be brutal without a burning internal desire that's fueling you. There are many motivations that can propel you forward, but anything less that full conviction will likely end in heartbreak.

author: Josh
content:
Might be a little soul crushing but he has a bigger advantage than all of us rn because of his age so it wouldn’t hurt to be a little blunt. Might get his butt in gear. But I’d basically frame it as it can’t be a career and won’t be a career until you build d the numbers. Being an artist is being a business owner. Except it’s more like owning a business that invests its money in slot machines. 

His first step is gonna be writing 100 songs. Because they’re all gonna be not that great. I think it’s important to instill the idea of not being precious with your art early on because I think we all spent way too long on that one song when we were 18 and it was awful anyway. 

Then he needs to connect with other people with the same goals as him. Find or build a community. Play shows as often as possible and see how people react to your music. Save up the little bit of money for studio time. 

After doing that for like a year or two start recording and keep networking.

author: peterlabberton

He took me out to a build site one time and just scared me away from doing it—“if you design a building and even 30% of it comes out how you want after the developers and the city have their way you’ll be very lucky… this job is a total hassle and pain in the ass dealing with x y and z other thing…” etc. I really think he was doing exactly this: if it scares him away, it’s not for him. It did scare me away, but my family saying how music wasn’t going to be viable and I need to focus on something else didn’t. 🤷🏻‍♂️ I think it’s a good test of where your real focus and drive lies.

author: Deleted User
content:
@joshbonanno said:

i think the premise of this stems from the constant fight that i feel like we all face... 

wanting something to be the "best" it can be (at least in our personal minds and perspectives) vs the sometimes reality that we are hired to do a "job" and not everything is going to meet our expectations of what we personally think is great. 

because at the end of the day, we aren't the artist. In some cases, even the intended audience. with that said, if someone is looking to hire me and my immediate gut says "this isn't great, everyone before me did a bad job and i am going to have to save the day" i immediately question if i am even the right person for the job as thats obviously not an attitude i really want to bring in to a collaborative process with others constantly thinking badly about everyone before me. 

/ might mean i just dont understand the record itself. in the cases that i do take the job though, i typically just try and shift my mindset to think and assume that it made it to me this far and everyone signed off on it. 

so who am i to say its "bad" or needs fixing outside of what i was hired to do? maybe the bad vocal comps and slightly off time drums made it through the production stage because they liked the raw human nature of it? maybe their idea of life/color/mojo is different than mine and they're more sensitive to certain sounds etc....idk. 

this is maybe mainly more of a response pertaining to what i do as primarily mixing day in and day out and maybe doesn't translate as much to the production world. but i still think theres some connected ideas in that line of thinking. if the artist is happy with a sloppily played acoustic take that feels uninspired...you re-tracking and double tracking guitars that are on the grid and feel exciting to you doesn't always make it "better" in the artists mind or vision.

author: Zakhiggins
SoundsLikeJoe
content:
Not shit talking BBC, or my own products... but on a BIZ TIP for younger me out there: Don't assume there is no reason to push for players because you have great sequencing skills and $50k worth of sample libraries.  When the production company wants world-class sound, and it's your job to create the budget...   knowing that sample libraries can only take you so far is key to explaining to the client WHY they should allocate budget for humans. "I can create this with just the computer, and it will sound great....  but it won't sound like your example.  There's a real VALUE to humans playing the music and that extra 10% of the quality you're looking for requires a studio session with real players" 

Instant path to budget upgrade.  Suddenly the expense makes sense to them.  Now you get the pleasure of hiring all your friends and deliverying something that sounds top notch...  and you can take the client on a mind-blowing field-trip.  It took me years to learn this trick...   clients don't want to pay mountains of money extra for you to sit in front of your computer and massage CC lanes....  and if they have a mindblowing time in the studio and the track sounds ALIVE?  You win six different ways.

author: Dereck Blackburn
content: The only thing I have to contribute is I work with folks in the 23 - 35 age range regularly (Im 44) and younger people who are HUNGRY to move up and ahead in their career get easily frustrated that things don't just happen for them when they're feeling like they're sacrificing a lot for very little recognition. There is also a lot of pushing and pulling the artists to fit their expectations instead of serving the art and letting nature take its course. Specifically theres a lot of "I can't wait to help you realize the full expression of your music and art when we work together!!!!!!!!" kind of vibe which is great internally but puts off older artists a little bit. I've seen it a lot over the last couple years with young producers and engineers and I wonder if its because of the pandemic, honestly. The whole "check list to success" thing is another good point. Some things are not easily repeatable or scalable with the expectation of the same result every time.

This is going off of a fairly small sample size though (a charter public high school and a private music school) and I stopped teaching in schools after about a year. I definitely got a lot of other things out of my Master's program (skills, network, artistic development, my Protools perpetual license, etc) and the degree would qualify me for certain academic jobs if I were to ever go that direction in the future. My main recommendation for grad school would be to do it for more reasons than just the certification and potential pay increase, and ideally find a program where the costs are mostly or entirely covered.

author: nachomaquieira
content:
It totally makes sense to hope a new release does well cause it can feel like a big boost for motivation and your everyday life. But putting too much pressure or expectation on it can be really tough later on mental health. Most of the time, music/realeses doesn’t drastically change our lives; it’s more about the connection with the people we create it with and staying in the flow of doing what we love.

Over the years, I’ve learned to ease up on the *what could happen* side of "big projects", and instead focus more on truly connecting with the music and the artist in the most genuine, loving, and positive way I can. That’s what brings out our best work and, in turn, leads to better opportunities in the future: musically, financially, and in terms of personal and professional growth.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I was going to discuss this a bit on my birthday, but a big part of the reason I give Cian so much guff on here publicly is because I saw a lot of pearl clutching for a second. “This producer works me too hard”, “this person insulted my hair, can I work with them” etc. 

A music career is rarely experienced entirely alone. You WILL have to deal with other people, and often time they’re… “artists”. They’ll be mercurial. They’ll be quirky. They’ll take work. And that’s ok. A huge part of making a living in this business is to learn how to stick to your guns without being just completely insufferable. 

I hate Cian’s speakers. I hate him even more. But he makes a mean martini, so I go over to his house for work, and even recommend him for things. That’s how the real world works. 

Find something in someone you like, and cultivate something interesting about yourself. Then go diamond.

author: Zack Hames
content: This may be weird advice, but sometimes I just say “sure!” (Or completely disregard depending on context) To certain ideas or mix notes and choose not to address them again. It doesn’t always work but sometimes people just say stuff to say stuff, and they may listen to the mix several times again and get used to how it is and not even want the change later or remember they said anything. I know that may sound insulting but I just dealt with this exact thing, and that did save me a few times. If they brought it up again I tried to meet in the middle. I started experimenting with this once I realized being super honest/straight forward/transparent can actually slow down the process without any benefit. This may apply to more commercial productions where people don’t really want a “no” or a “why not” they just want a yes man and a person to get the job done. I hope that makes sense, I feel like some of the other options you’ve definitely already came up with. Sometimes making your case with the utmost confidence can also work! (Not something I do often but it absolutely can work)

author: peterlabberton
content: Not quite as slick as the keyboard shortcut, but: before I had the monitor controller/loads of outputs, I’d route the “mix output” bus internally to an aux; I’d also make a “ref output” bus. author: cian riordan
content: Not a full-time mastering engineer, but I have prepped plenty of masters for vinyl reproduction. Typically, I would try and find a way to bring down the level significantly without changing the sonics too much. This is usually as simple as peeling back the limiter. I'll usually deliver for vinyl around -16 LUFS. There's really no reason for it to be any louder. And as for the output on limiters (assuming you're talking about non-vinyl preparation), I set mine at -0.1 dBFS and if asked to deliver MFiT, will set to -0.8 dBFS.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@Zakhiggins the best producers in the world are great because of this. getting the best out of an artist/ vocalist. your job should be getting the best performance. most young artists change their vibe around a fancy mic in a studio. some of them show up and kill it. your job is to adapt and find that vibe quickly, while being super comfortable. this job is way more psychology and vibe than technical know how!

we recorded the hives vocals on Tik Boom with an SM7 on a straight mic stand in front of Pelle's live wedge monitors. HE knew that's how he could rock out the most and get the best vocal.

eric valentine gave Adam from Taking Back Sunday a neumann hand held condenser on a long cable so he could move around the room and perform.

i just figured out how to edit them after the fact. they weren't as clean as standing in front of a U47 with a pop screen. but they sounded fucking awesome

author: junior.frigo
content:
Hey all! Been loving the live shows but fairly new to the server so feel free to point me in the right direction if there's a better thread for my question. Wondering what tools and habits people are using for medium to long term planning and vision casting, for lack of a better term, especially when busy?

Had what I would consider my first really busy year as a producer last year. Worked on 75 songs, most of them full instrumental productions taking them from a demo, playing / recording everything, and often mixing. It was a really exciting year but I found I spent most of the time being reactive, rather than proactive, just trying to stay on top of getting things out the door on time! 

What do y'all do to make sure you get time thinking about what you'd like to see happen in your career (everything from people you want to work with, music you want to create, gear you want to purchase), and organize it in an actionable way so that your time spent making stuff for other people also takes you where you want to go long-term? Thanks!

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@David Fuller it seems like the Jon Castelli "finisher" role is going to encompass mastering at some point soon. everyone is already "mixing" as they produce and write (in the traditional sense of balancing and eq'ing and compressing). then someone like jon takes *the existing mix* and finishes it. the argument of having an experienced ear outside perspective is totally correct. that's what a mixer now is becoming. then from there a mastering engineer does... another even more subtle layer of sonic refinement but only to the 2 track bounce? and then decides how loud it will be? i get that this has some value, but based on the evolution of the technology and the roles of "mixers" these days, it seems like hiring a mastering engineer is going to become a luxury equivalent to hiring a second co-mixer or something. or getting real strings on a record or something. 

why spend the money if you already have one sonic finisher?

author: cian riordan
content: And it will go down and down the chain. Why hire a mixing engineer when the producer gets it so close? Or why hire a producer when the artists demos are so good that you can just release that? Why have a songwriter when the artists just write their own songs? I don't disagree with you at all. I know that this is the case and am sure that my pirate ship is sailing in shallow waters... it's only a matter of time before I wash ashore. While I do applaud the evolution of the music making process and the ingenuity of the players moving the needle, if I *were* to make a stupid line graph, I don't think the quality of the work will rise as fast as high as the increase in efficiency... it's likely to invert.

author: Deleted User
content:
Hmm. I’m a young person in early 20s, so also seeking advice/people’s thoughts on this.

Wouldn’t you say it would be better to be decent at all of the things mentioned above for paths like producer? It isn’t required to be good at all of things because hiring other people is always an option, but starting out- I’m working with projects with lower budgets where people can barely afford to hire a producer. 

I want to have one strong path, and strength within those skill sets- but I feel like being well rounded wouldn’t hurt if there is one clear path I want to work on. And it seems to me that the path encompasses many different skills. For example, I would work on my instrumental skills, engineering skills, and arrangement skills- but I wouldn’t necessarily seek to pursue these career paths unless I was asked to because I know that primary focus is in production. I would still take gigs in different areas if the pay my bills, but if I get to a point where I can make full living exclusively from production work- I will not take other gigs unless I’m passionate enough to the point I wouldn’t mind doing them for free. To sum up my thoughts or desires on this- I want to build proficiencies in all areas because I believe they are part of the path I want to go through. Although I wouldn’t necessarily pursue a career in those areas I’m developing but I will still take the gigs until I’m paying all my bills and able to build proper savings solely from one thing I would ultimately want to do. 

It may sound like I’ve already made up my mind, but I’m eager to hear people’s thoughts on this because this is something I’ve been thinking about for a long time especially because I hear people say “niche down” or “focus on one thing”.

author: jantrit
content: I worked in kitchens for a long time, it allowed me to make some cash and live but also have flexibility to take music and studio jobs when they would come around. After moving to the states I found more restaurant work but kept it to only fri/sat/sun and tried to focus the rest of the week to build contacts and do studio stuff. I got super lucky with my boss who was also in the music thing and very understanding about calling out. It eventually got to the stage where I had to call out like 3 weekends in a row so I made the jump to doing the studio stuff full time. So far it’s been working out and I’ve been lucky to keep a good basis of projects, supplementing quiet periods with studio build stuff. It can be super stressful relying 100 percent on the music thing and it’s ultimately different strokes for diff folks. I’ve seen some people who get really burnt out taking music stuff that they don’t like to pay the bills and conversely I’ve seen people getting burnt out doing other stuff that’s not music getting effected in the same way. Ultimately whatever keeps ya happy and works for you is awesome, burn out is real.

author: Deleted User
content:
From my experience of going to music school and taking a whole bunch of courses that are all over the place in terms of lane of focus- school can offer almost too much. It helps to take some time to digest the information, I had this issue when I was in college and had a chat with some of the graduates and they said it took them years after graduating to decompose information that was learned. If you have doubts on if you should continue it may be useful to take some time off and spend on doing what you wanted to do, continuing to connect with people, or even just take breaks altogether to take a breeze of fresh air, live in outside world. Being in school kind of made me live in a bubble and getting out of that was really precious to me. 

Degree is just a piece of paper but academic settings can widen horizons of what you can access on your own in the future without having to rely on someone to feed the knowledge/information. It was very chaotic when I took a whole bunch of unrelated courses in college but they all offered me wide insights on what I could dig deeper into in the future. Did I transform as much as others that focused on one lane (eg. engineering) - then I would say no but I created my own program to gain things that would take me more than a decade to have access to. I wasn’t able to retain everything but it unlocked the ways so I can go there when I need to. 

It always sucked having no time to work on my own stuff, but I saw it as a training period  of my life rather than practical period of life. 

My case is slightly different than yours because I went to college straight without having much real world experience. But TLDR; I think semester or a year off would give you what you need without aborting any of the options!

author: Zack Hames
content:
Schools not important. Education is.

I went to a trade school for audio, a working recording studio that also had very well made and structured classes, walked away with a portfolio and having had been lead and assistant engineer on dozens of sessions. I don’t blame anyone for hating their school, hating the idea of school, etc. I just got lucky and I owe my entire career to that experience. 

Audio is not a field where the piece of paper means a god damn thing. It might help you when applying for more corporate adjacent jobs but I work full time, salary, for the production team for marketing at a huge company, im probably the only person in the entire marketing department that doesn’t have an actual college degree.

author: Slow Hand
content:
These tools are magic, but they're not a miracle. It still requires work and understanding. It's just a different kind of work than we're used to doing. We shouldn't expect it read our mind and generate something amazing. It's still a computer.

This is something that Jon Castelli has touched as one of his unspoken services and something that we all do. Because of Jon's depth and breadth of musical understanding he's able to interpret prompts given to him by his clients and interpret their abstract requests with a well-realized result that hits the mark. That's a pro service that AI's still can't cover. They can't bring deep contextual understanding and interpret meaning.

As a client, if I hire an illustrator to commission a specific image I'm not just hiring them for their technical ability to render images. The best illustrators are going to have a broad and deep awareness of all styles, modes of presentation, and compositional techniques. They're going to use all of their experience and knowledge to interpret what my needs are and deliver on that. That's not a trivial thing to do. AI's are getting closer, but they're not mind readers.

Even the best contractors have to deal with clients who don't know how to ask for what they want; the "I'll know it when I see it" type of client. In the case of these AI tools we're the "client" who need to learn how to ask for what we want.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Not an answer to your question, but reminded me of a dynamic that I observed in my time assisting at major London studios:

There was a noticeable number of US clients (artists + their entourages, certain producers, and especially writers - usually in pop or hip hop) who treated assistants like “the help” / waiting staff / taxi drivers / some menial worker they felt was beneath them. The first few times it happened, it was kind of shocking, and very off-putting.

Of course there are going to be bell ends from every country (and there were plenty of exceptions - I've had many incredible sessions with North American clients, and some gross sessions with UK clients too), but it happened enough to wonder whether maybe it's a cultural thing?

Does this hold water with you US folks’ experience? FWIW, I can’t imagine anyone in this Discord treating anyone like that, let alone their colleagues. And of course, my personal experience is probably weighted 80/20 UK/international.

author: austenballard
content:
> There was a noticeable number of US clients (artists + their entourages, certain producers, and especially writers - usually in pop or hip hop) who treated assistants like “the help” / waiting staff / taxi drivers / some menial worker they felt was beneath them. The first few times it happened, it was kind of shocking, and very off-putting.

I want to add to what Ruairí and Matt B said with another perspective. I've had the privilege of working in some very professional settings, where everyone needs to fade into the background to do their jobs properly, and that's absolutely the case at higher levels. And it makes things work. And everyone's cool about it.

But much of my work has been as producer, assistant producer or project manager/fixer for people working at decidedly lower levels. 

And idk how it is in other countries, but we have a glut of people here in the US who have a certificate from a for-profit recording school that says they know what they're doing, who think they're *the shit* for being in the room with some viral star off YouTube/Instagram/TikTok. But don't know how to use a damn patch bay. 

And when you're on the come up, especially as a writer or producer, you interact with a lot of these people, and you get REALLY sick of them REALLY fast. So that might be the source of some of the condescension you see. It's hard not to get jaded when you have to wade through so much incompetence. I feel like a bitter old man just typing this paragraph tbh but I hope I'm not the only one with this experience.

author: cian riordan
content: When I first got hired by Eric as his assistant, I had already built a multi room studio complex and was making a living producing and engineering records. When I landed in LA for the first session, my mindset was “I can’t wait to show off all the knowledge and experience I had.” I very quickly ran up against the “nobody-gives-an-absolute-fuck-what-I-have-to-say-about-anything” wall. It was very clear that I was there to sit in the back of the room until I was asked to do something… order food, help with a mic setup, shuffle cars in the parking lot, etc. Not to mention working for someone like Eric who is extremely self sufficient… he was terrible at asking me to do things. It was always just quicker for him to do it… even if it meant getting up from the seat and walking all the way across the studio to adjust something. I made the absolute mistake in my second or third week of suggesting something to the drummer in the band after a performance. Eric overheard and pulled me aside. Basically said something along the lines of “yo, you really can’t do that. If you have an idea, run it through me. Absolutely inappropriate, however well intentioned it was. This was really deflating to me. I went from running the show at my own place to spending 14 hrs a day waiting for something to do.
