author: LAPhill
content:
This has happened several times in the classical world, where unfinished works are completed either by apprentices of the composer, or someone that took it upon themselves to complete the work. More recently, when James Horner died during the scoring of The Magnificent Seven, his assistant/arranger finished the score. 

The difference between this and the pop example is there is no AI technology used to imitate the person, which feels like a parlor trick to me. I am all for finishing unfinished art, but unless there was an express wish from the artist to use their voice via AI tech, then I say make it known what it is. Finish the production by bringing in other people to celebrate the spirit of the original voice. Pay tribute. Sort of like Japanese Kintsugi, where you're drawing attention to what it's not to elevate what it is. (This is not the intention of kintsugi exactly, but I can't think of a better metaphor at the moment).

author: ALXCPH
content:
Certainly! Here’s a more detailed explanation of the chord choices:

D - - - | G - - - | Bb - - - | A - - - |
D - - - | G - - - | Bb - C#7 - | F#m7b5 B7 E7 |
The first four bars are in D major and use the I-IV-V chords (D-G-A). The fifth and sixth bars repeat this progression. In the third bar, we use the Neapolitan chord (Bb major), which is a chromatic chord that is built on the lowered second scale degree. It’s called the Neapolitan chord because it was commonly used in classical music from Naples. In the seventh bar, we start to modulate to E minor by using a ii-V-I progression in that key (F#m7b5-B7-E7). This progression is commonly used to modulate to a new key in jazz and other styles of music.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.

author: Zack Hames

author: Zack Hames
content:
This is a lovely idea. No one’s gonna risk their bacon in at least the USA economy. Educating our clients and learning the industry so that they can find viable ways to be more financially viable is a good way to get a return on our end. (Providing value, being an expert)

We as engineers get money from artists and labels. Understanding how they can make money may help us, help them, help us, etc. 

most small bands make an album, don’t want to spend any money because they have 0 idea how to make money off of it after it’s done. Whether that’s ignorance, the albums not that great, or lack of effort, depends on the artist and project. 

It does bum me out. But I have 0 idea how to address this on a large level. I think just understanding this career is the long game and if you do good work long enough it’ll eventually pay off.

Sometimes you do a record and you lose money or make almost nothing and spend months on it. Another time you’ll spend an hour or two and make a ton of money. It balances out.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
In most instances, I feel I am fairly remunerated for my work at this stage. On the way to this point though, I did the grind and experienced the impact of that lifestyle on my mental and physical health, and on my personal life and relationships.

I'd rather people coming up now wouldn't have to endure the shitness that can abound, and to that end I sourced thoughts from a bunch of engineers, assistants, producers, mixers, and studios in the UK at the end of last year.

The list below was assembled from those conversations, and details some basic working conditions for music technicians working on a day rate basis (runners, assistants, tape/PT ops, engineers - not mixers, MEs, producers, or songwriters) that would bring us more in line with what have long been established and taken for granted by clients and employers in the comparable industries of theatre and film.

I'm not talking about bringing the industry to its knees here - just about establishing basic working conditions to safeguard the mental and physical health of our friends and colleagues.

I recognise that there are conditions specific to our industry and the nature of our work that would make some of these points less than straightforward to establish, so I'd love to hear everyone's thoughts on the below - whether they're reasonable, actionable, etc.

Pick some holes.

author: Deleted User
content:
another one I’m thinking is how a lot of artists are funding their projects through gofundme or kickstarter type ask. 

The issue a lot of times is that we (musicians, engineers, producers, writers) are getting paid by artists paying out of pocket, whom also need a day job to support what they do most of the times. So what ends up happening is that we’re struggling relying on making a living paid by those who are also struggling. 

The culture of music should shift towards the direction where if the artist is able to provide enough values for people to want to hear more work from them, then people should be down to fund it. The issue is that everyone’s expenses are more likely going to be prioritizing commodities over intangible products like music. NFT seemed to attempt commodifying music, but just like modern art paintings- they just became a method of investment for monetization, avoiding taxes, or status; nor it was accessible enough for everyday people to want to get into it.

author: Barbara
content:
Even though I understand where you come from with this - I guess everyone relates and/or feels more emotionally connected with some projects than others - I think we should own what we do. If you're recording/mixing/producing, do it as best as you can. That can mean passing it on to someone else (and handle this part with care, in my opinion, is also a part of the job). But if you end up going all the way, it still is a worthy project, you should still give it 100% of yourself. Learn something new and useful. And if you do, you should be proud of having your name on something you know you gave your best (even if the rest of it wasn't ideal, your part was the best you could do, at least in a certain moment in time).

So, I'm all for: work in it, own it. But make sure you do your best all the times and always learn something.

author: Deleted User
content:
This can be controversial, but to execute C no matter what artist says or wants to do and present it. That way they can at least have a tangible result to compare it with. Instead of explaining, it’s better to do it and show it.

My humble take: our job is not necessarily doing what we’re told. it is to take their vision, and take it to a place where they could say “wow- I didn’t know this is what I wanted but this is what I want now”. Which I think is the taste and perspective factor. 

It is case by case of course and some artists could come in with A to Z manual of what they want, which can be cool- or not. I personally find those boring, unless I really admire their vision and it just feel like an honor to be a part of it. I think being a yes man can be a quick way to become dispensable. But someone who is willing to serve by giving you some friction that can turn into some heat 🔥 can be someone they find trustworthy and interesting. It’s case by case dependent, some people need perfect aerodynamics to accelerate their vision, and I don’t think that’s necessarily being a yes man- but rather about just being the right fit for the project and being someone who is fully on board to do what they are asking. 

But I think more importantly- it’s okay to miss. If they don’t like it - then scrap it or give it another go. And it’s also fine if you end up not being the one for the project

author: BatMeckley
content:
The guy I learned it from (Doug McKean) was just a key command Jedi and had muscle memory on the keyboard, but I mapped out the the three main tools on to the buttons of an expert trackball and it became an absolute necessity for about 15 years of my career. Allowed me to not only be faster than most everyone but also there’s an intuitiveness about it that actually helps you make music, because not having to take your hand off the mouse or “move it to a certain part of the screen to get it to switch tools” just removes another barrier between what you want and how to get there. A bit like learning an instrument to the point where you can just jam and not have to think about how to play it… music just starts to flow. 

The downside was if I ever had to  work without it I felt really handicapped, almost like I was in a different DAW.

author: Slow Hand
content:
100% agreed. You're hired.

There's an old bit of design advice that's always stuck with me: "Always imagine the thing you're designing within it's next biggest context." 

If you're designing a chair, how does it relate to the dining table set? If you're designing a dining table set, how does it relate to the room? If you're on a team, how do you support everyone else?

It's so crucial to understand how things relate to one another. In the case of DJ'ing between sets what role is the music playing? Is it there to warm people up? Is it aligned with the feel of the show? Is it supposed to draw attention to itself? Is it supposed to wind people down? These questions seem so simple, but I continually observe people at events failing to match their environment.

author: LAPhill
content: I'd venture that most of us start out as generalists to some degree. For one, when starting out, you haven't necessarily found which lane you gravitate towards so it's in your interest to try a bunch of things. Second, for folks earlier in their career with not a lot of money to realize their vision, it's cost effective to do as much yourself as possible. And the tools make it easier than ever before to do so. I see it as part of the journey, though there's no reason you have to close yourself off to other areas of interest as you grow.

author: Deleted User
content:
Fair enough. Everything that concerns “me” starts with working on myself. 

But my belief as someone who makes art; it is my job to be concerned about it, and spend time pondering on it. I’m not responsible or I can’t be for it, it would be an arrogance and narcissism (or ego centric frame of mind at the very least) to believe that I’m responsible for it or matters in any way - but I think believing that what I do would have no impact on others is inconsiderate. 

I believe it would help people find things they like if everyone alivned their taste/values to their individuality; rather than the idea of their individuality.

Re: Korea; 
you bring up a very good point about this. Korea is an extreme case of collectivism over individualism, and my obsession about this probably stems from growing up in that background. I only truly understand two cultures from first hand experience and that is Korean and North American; but it seems that no matter how culture forms, human nature will always be relevant and it’s in our nature to be want to be accepted, feel included. 

I believe that American individualist propaganda is a lie. It’s not about being yourself, it’s rather about finding a box to put yourself in for sake of convenience. i believe it mostly has to do with consumerism and the complexity of the society from immigration and various cultures coming together; converging / diverging at different pace even amongst those that share the same cultural roots- which then later becomes nu-gen X-American culture, which is different from the culture of X. (X being a country/ethnic group)

content: curious if any other nashville people will chime in here…but my experience is that it depends.. nashville leans heavy on country obviously so if that’s the world you are in….then yeah…those numbers are probably about right. smaller to mid tier pop leaning world where i find myself doing a lot here in town… it’s a bit less i feel or have experienced at least…there are jack of all trade guys doing $250-$350 type stuff that is fine and they get hired enough but the $450-$650 type specialized people like myself are the ones taken a bit more serious and maybe “known”…above $700 though i feel like you start to price yourself out of things and they get taken to LA world…again, just my two cents and personal experience… the production rates here are also just a lot less than LA which is part of the issue…no one is going to pay $750 for a mix when the production itself was only $750-$1k…

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: Seriously though....  this was inspired by a pop track string/winds  arrangement.  You'd think "well of course all the sample libraries I bought can do that just as well"  but not imxp....  its that the sample libraries can do "an adequate" job and satisfythe need.  But once you hire world-class players and play it live into mics....  for me it was instantly "we could've bought every sample library and programmed for days but never gotten this quality" in the tiny details.  The bow sounds. The players breathing together. Their adaptation to dynamics. The aleatoric sections where advanced techniques were improvised. Samples can be amazing and do things humans can't...  but the inverse is also true.  There are many context where it's got to be live players, or else your track is just "adequate"

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: Not saying "samples are bad" ....  but sometimes they can only be so good.  That extra final 5% seems to only be found in the fingers and mind of a master player responding to the musical situation. If your lucky enough to have the budget and to hire the right people...  its something special.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I don’t think this is a hot take. Wind & String instruments and the human voice are all kinda impossible to make into a virtual instrument in a completely human sounding way. 

But, a world-class ensemble is often a little out of reach for a lot of self-producing artists and young folks just getting into it, and while something to strive for, shit talking BBC orchestra in this context feels shitty. 

The key is to do interesting things with what you have. Can’t hire the LSO? Make something intentional that gives the same feeling if not the same Sonics.

author: LAPhill
content:
This usually means that you're part of a union contract and would be receiving union wages (at least a few hundred dollars, up to thousands, depending on the duration and type of work). As in, you pay work dues as a portion of your union income. 

If you're not receiving money, I'd question why you're expected to pay work dues. You could either talk to your people at Capitol or ask the union about it. There's always a small chance they're fishing to get union people caught working non-union sessions, but usually it's because someone filed a union contract and didn't let you know you're on it.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'll start by saying that I don't know much about the music ed world, so perhaps a masters in music production will be legitimately helpful. I don't mean to dissuade because I don't know that space. 

Focusing on a subject for her masters like pedagogy or child development might be worth considering because they seem more fundamental to her stated aims of modernizing public music education. A production expert can be hired to advise on implementation, but if she wants to change the space, that seems like a more fundamental place to start.

author: peterlabberton

author: spectrummasters
content:
.....agreed. Im not shooting down his message. I would only have reservations around his weighting of the 40% is creation, 60% is world-building for garnering attention. Is this sustainable long term for musicians? Can you balance that much time given to your art and then even more to finding your audience?  Its an open question in my mind, partly born from having seen how musicians and djs in my community in London have quietly built lifelong careers in UKG and Drum n Bass on the back of pure devotion to their crafts and not so much pouring even more effort into self promotion. 
Its an alternative approach imho, that has now delivered a good few of them to a balanced, apparently affluent lifestyle in their 50s. Balanced as in, found the time to have children and build a private life with family as well as pursue a music career. And still going hard on the music , same as they always did.
Will Teddy Swims be burnt out at 50? Will he still love making music? 
There are quicker (and legal) ways to make money that enable us to be just as creative Giving  100% of your time to anything just to have a chance at the slim odds of making a living seems unwise imho.

author: chrissorem
content: This is an important balance you brought up, we have to constantly find ways of keeping the session flowing but also make sure we take time to get things right.  No one wants to watch someone get drum sounds for hours or any sounds for hours yet we expect the results to sound as if we did.  We have to stay out of the way but always be prepared to catch someone falling.  This job is hard, there are many details that go into making  a session go well.  Id suggest thinking about the things you feel need to go further. Are there ways you can be ahead of the curve ?  Are there ways that you can surprise the room and you can say “I  actually just took care of that, we can move on to the next thing”? We have to be steps ahead of everyone else in the room. Some things do in fact take time and you can decide if doing certain things are disruptive to the flow and you might need to bust it while everyone is getting a coffee or telling the room  “ hey gang I need 15 mins to take care of …..”

author: Slow Hand
content:
I can understand the trepidation here. Now that Canva own Affinity, it's not yet clear what their strategy is. My guess is that there are a few reasons for this play:

1. Affinity Studio is now a loss leader for Canva's other offerings, like their (just announced) supplemental AI tool set or their enterprise plans, which I suspect are a big portion of their income compared to their Affinity suite licenses.

2. It eats into Adobe's market share. Making a very competitive alternative to Adobe's flagship software and then offering it for free encourages adoption by users who are ready to jump ship from their Adobe subscriptions or who need software like this and are fine without Adobe's cutting-edge tools (like me).

There are some positive examples of high-level *free* software that is continues to thrive with no sign of being abandoned, or compromised. Like DaVinci Resolve or Reaper (which is effectively free). There are also some great examples of open source software getting a new lease on life by their steward companies. Namely Musescore and Audacity's recent revamps. 

Now Affinity isn't open source, but Musegroup have a large full-time development team that seem to be getting by just fine developing what is effectively free software. If they can do it, then Affinity likely can.

Here's hoping Canva have done the math right before setting out on this course.

author: Zakhiggins
content:
I had another job up until the pandemic actually, was working 20+ hours a week, and doing college while working on music, then the pandemic hit and the place I worked at shut down, the business is fully closed now but that's another story. Right now with the government restrictions in Ireland, sooo many businesses are closing and it's near impossible to get a job. 
So my college then went remote, meaning I had alot more free time on my hands, and no steady income.. This kinda forced me to go all in on production. College finished last May for summer, and I worked hard as fuck on being a better mixer and producer (with the virtual help of Matt and Jon) and also tried to figure ways of making money from it.. Apart from working with local artists (there aint too many here in Dublin) most of the work I got and still get was through soundbetter.com, after a while of grinding I got to a stage where I was and still am, only making a little bit less than the job I was in before, so I can at least survive lol.

Basically long story short, I'm actually kinda full time music right now while finishing off my college degree. Then I've to make a decision of whether I remain fulltime music here, go part time and get a job from my degree, or move to the US or London to pursue music there. It'll prob be one of the latter 2 options cos the scene here is very much in it's early days and not sure if a sustainable career could be had.
Also as I said here before I'm very fortunate to live in a country where you can get free education, so debt isn't a worry for me. 

That's my long ass story anyways, since you asked 🤣

author: Zakhiggins
content:
I don't wanna talk bad about anyone but I've been following kneesovertoesguy for a good few years, even though I agree with alot of what he says I'd be careful with him for sure, he used to have a really good system with ATG and good coaches around him, but they've since left him and he's become alot more of a business man than a coach I feel, I know his training works for him and some others but it definitely isn't 1 size fits all, I know personally people that  have signed up to his programmes and have gotten much worse knees than they went in with, and when they asked him about it they were blocked on everything by him.. There's a lot of people out there with similar unconventional principles to him (like putting load thru knees over toes and back flexion etc) but are definitely much more educated on the topics they're speaking on, and won't block you when you confront them..

Id personally reccomend the likes of Jeffery Wolfe (@theflexibull), moses Bernard (@mosesbernard), Dan van zandt (@flexibility.research), Nicholas Simpson (@nicholassimpson_)

I've reached out to them before and they're always very helpful, nice people, I know they often do live videos themselves, maybe it could be worth asking one of them to do a podcast with you..
I definitely don't consider myself an expert on this stuff, but I feel I have a very good base knowledge on health and fitness, I've been heavily involved in track and feild most my life, competed internationally too, so keeping strong, flexible and pain free is definitely something I've experience in lol

author: peterlabberton
content: Guilt not so much, but anxiety—around money—absolutely. I’ve been freelancing full time as an engineer/producer/mixer/drummer for 9 years now, 6 in the Bay Area and now 3 in LA. Easily the first half of my time in the bay was just constant anxiety about how I’ll pay rent/will I work/blah blah. Then things got more solid and I could take my foot off the gas a bit. Was able to relax and feel confident I could make ends meet. Then I blew it all up and moved to LA to start over again! Ha. Not *really* start over again 100% since I had a lot more experience and a tiny bit of a track record, but I’m only now beginning to feel that corner turning again, just a bit. I definitely feel that for me, those feelings correlate to how comfortable I am on, I guess you’d say, the business side and how it’s working out. Creatively I feel like taking time away is always helpful.

author: Slow Hand
content: Keeping your rates above a certain standard will passively filter out the clients that you probably don't want anyway: those who might negotiate too hard or nickel-and-dime you in a way that devalues you and your work. At the same time, demanding a certain amount also sends a strong signal to would-be clients that you're of a particular standard; a professional, and that you should be treated as such.

author: Zack Hames
content: What daw are you using? Also preach on there being 0 videos. All the editing I learned was from audio school actually. Big picture, just don’t be afraid to do whatever it takes to make it right. Cutting, nudging, stealing parts from other parts and placing them in different areas as needed (even just syllable sounds or cymbal decays or dead air) cross fading properly to make the edit “invisible”. And if you’re in pro tools, beat detective is huge if you can learn it’s quirks.

author: skinnybreakfast
content:
Sorry for the book incoming. But this is plaguing my mind. Has there been an in-depth discussion on live or in discord yet about musicians on tiktok? 

It's a crazy scene of selling your creative soul for 1 minute of attempting to go viral. and then if you do get a popular video, whatever that one was - that is now your thing... singing into a trash can doing RHCP covers... ok, now do another 100 of those.  I see so much talent on there, genuine talent and artists who have worked hard on their craft getting 10 views due to the algo... once the algo has tried your vid on a few people and it didn't stick the vid is dead... so it's totally hit and miss based on your first small sample of viewers.

I see this having a huge impact in many ways. On the plus - you are getting exposure to incredible new ideas, skills, trends, methods for being creative... on the negative it's demotivating to the nth degree, and cheapening the creative process, in my opinion.

Matt and Jon recently talked about track lengths getting shorter and shorter, now 2 minutes is the normal. Partly due to the attention span of people... well what is this going to do... 1 minute pop tracks incoming? Just gimme the hook in 30 seconds and let's move on please. :p. How can we get young people to lay on the floor and listen to 10 minute vinyl tracks again? In my opinion humanity NEEDS this :)) 

I also swear I've heard the influence of trending memes from tiktok coming through in music in the charts, but cannot really back this up.

What's everyone else's thoughts? I have a friend in LA who says everyone has gone crazy there for tiktok fame? 😛

author: cian riordan
content: I think it's safe to say that different roles have various degrees of influence on the success of a record. It's silly to think that a mastering engineer spending a day mastering an album will have as much impact as an artist spending years writing & producing that very record. I also think all of these various roles within the record making process have evolved over time... the creative roles have become more technical and the technical roles have become more creative. Only a matter of time before the venn diagram below becomes one circle.

author: hendrick
content:
I agree with matt that hiring a mastering engineer is a luxury in the present day tbh. Most of the records that I get to mix or produce I'm expected to deliver a finished product ready to release. However when a lot of things are at stake (label release) it's almost 100% sure that a mastering engineer will take care to finish the record, do some QC and especially keep a human touch to the art. Would a co-mixer be able to do that? possibly, depending on their skillset/experience.

with the use of AI and other systems the expense of hiring a mastering engineer is already fading away but only for projects that are less risky. Say, if you have a tape library of 500 symphonic recordings and need to submit it for streaming so a few folks can listen to it, labels will most likely get an automated system for that to make sure that the standard levels are ok and that it translates well. I'm sure there would be a hungry mastering engineer willing to get that done but the industry is past that era

author: Eric Martin
content:
As long as there’s someone out there that has listened/worked on more music than the person who is the Mixer or Producer and has a “technically better” or more accurate playback system than said producer there will be a viable job for the ME when it comes to releasing music IMO, not everyone will pay to do it, but the people who want to put out the “best work” will, the job will change, it already has many times, but the responsibility will stay.

FWIW at Abbey Road in the 50’s/60’s the new engineers started in the cutting room so that they learned exactly what was possible to put on the records as it was cut, then they gradually worked  their way back from cutting to working in the room with an artist.

I think this process is insanely valuable, I just did my first “true” tracking session in over a year and after mainly Mastering and Mixing for the last year/two my tracking mixes sounded dang finished.

author: peterlabberton
content:
👆🏻 This room is a crazy steal in LA, good dudes in there as well! I just moved out of the room down the hall.

Regarding moving out of the central part of LA: I fucking love it so far. My girlfriend’s work is out on this side of the valley, which is what brought us here. We’re technically in Chatsworth, but our place is in a pocket of unincorporated weirdness in the hills. If it felt like suburbia I’d fucking off myself, but it feels like a small town in New Mexico. (Used to film westerns out here.) If my girlfriend didn’t have a great job with an awful commute from our old place, we wouldn’t have moved—until maybe several years down the road buying a house in, like, Altadena or something. But here we are! Now I just drive a lil longer to get to a show or a bar, whenever I go to one. 🤷🏻‍♂️ Long story short: LA (and greater LA) is huge and if you look around you can find loads of different options.

Also I’ll say I would NOT have wanted to live where I am now when I first moved here. Living in Los Feliz was awesome for being central and meeting people/getting my bearings, and LA being LA maybe there was some superficial bullshit cachet to being able to say I live in the cool part of town. I am less oriented to the pop world specifically, but Los Feliz/Silverlake/Echo Park/Highland Park/Atwater are all the places where the shit I think is cool and exciting happens. If anyone is considering a move to LA, I’d really recommend finding a place close to where the shows/people are that you’re interested in. Live there and rent for a while.

author: peterlabberton
content:
Partly in light of recent Facebook… developments:

I would *very* happily leave Instagram—or make a private account and unfollow everyone except my actual friends—if I wasn’t worried that it would impact my work. I feel like I have anecdotal experience that, when I post more on Instagram, I work more. And so I keep at it even though Facebook/Instagram just generally bum me out—and are ruining society.*

I am a freelance engineer/mixer/etc. and rely almost completely on work for hire gigs, i.e. I’ve got basically no passive royalties coming in. I’ve gradually, recently gotten my name on a few bigger projects but by no means do I have random people hitting me up to work—the vast majority of my income comes from friends/acquaintances hiring me for their self-funded projects.

Has anyone else in a similar situation tried fully cutting the cord?

*BTW, this community is so rad, and I’m well aware it sprung out of Instagram. Life is complicated. 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: Zack Hames
content:
I didn't post on instagram from 2016 - 2021, then I started actively posting again, *strictly* about audio, music, engineering, projects. I have easily gotten 10+ projects this year from doing this. It's not all my work but it's been shockingly useful. THAT SAID, it is almost entirely from people I already knew, or friends of friends. You know this, but it's an effective way to keep YOU in people's front of mind for picking someone for a job, at least for independent projects.That's what it came down to. "Oh yeah, they are an engineer, I'll hit them up". A lot of work has been fully completed THROUGH the instagram DM's. It's genuinely insane to me but it's worked.

I think social media can and will be what you make of it. It's easy to be addicted (I definitely struggle with this) but 90% of what I am reading, ingesting, etc is all audio based. Lots of people post political stuff, news, or personal stuff and I can't entirely avoid it but for the most part I do compared to what I realize other people's feeds consist of.

I think instagram has worked for me, but it certainly won't make or break your career if you don't do good work in the first place. If you currently have 0 clients, it probably won't get you more clients. I legit think I have 300 followers which is embarrassingly low. My account is private. it still has worked for me, at this juncture in my career. I also have enjoyed the community aspect of engineers on insta and discord. 

Every interaction or project can lead to something new. That's why for a lot of people, saying "yes" to everything is the best at the beginning until you are doing so much that you have the freedom to say no.  thanks for coming to my Ted-X talk.

author: peterlabberton
content:
Right, yeah, I guess what else is there to do? Ha!

I got hired to mix something a few weeks ago that was self-recorded. I brought it along as far as I could but we were still unhappy with it. (Me, artist, and artist’s manager.) So I did some additional production and re-recorded some stuff. Now the client is happy but it still bums me out. Eh. I’m just really trying to—whenever possible—only put out work that I’m super pumped about, but, so it goes.

author: cian riordan
content: I juggled side-gigs for years while getting going -- but made a point for all of them to be temporary & extremely flexible. So many of my opportunities came last minute and having the ability to pivot and make things happen for people was extremely important. For example, I was living in the Bay Area working out of a studio when I reached out to Eric about assisting. He asked if I could come down to LA that weekend to interview/hang-out -- so I got on a plane. At the end of the weekend he hired me and basically said, "record starts in two weeks -- can you get down here?". I had to move out of my studio, pack up my life, find a place to live, and get down to make it happen. Obviously that was a great opportunity and most folks in my position would trip over themselves to make it happen -- but I always wondered had I had a day-job with real obligations and financial leverage over my life, would I have been able to make the timeline work... probably not!

author: peterlabberton
content: Lotta good answers so far so I’ll just say +1 to the above. I’ll *also* add that the ceiling for what you can earn here in music is *way* higher. I moved from San Francisco 5 years ago. I had a good thing going there and was well connected to a bunch of other full-time working music folks—you can charge way more in LA for your services than you can just about anywhere else. I’m now easily charging double what my friends back in the Bay Area are, in large part due to the environment in LA and the available work. Now, getting hired is an entirely different thing, but it’s worth remembering that, if and when you make the connections to start getting regularly hired, you can make enough to easily outpace the cost of living. (Caveat: I’m speaking as a mixer/engineer/drummer—if you’re more on the songwriting/spec production/artist side… 🤷🏻‍♂️)

author: Will Melones

author: Will Melones
content: It’s a trap for novice engineers who will have no clue what phase is until years into their careers. These two words have literally nothing to do with one another except for the coincidence that a symmetrical periodic wave like a sine can *appear* 180 degrees out of phase when the polarity is inverted

author: 1ggy
content: Flip the phase like flip the switch sounds better than shift the phase 180 degrees

author: Will Melones
content: Right, exactly. Real life is where it gets messy. Because you can phase shift two identical snare drum samples and they’re not going to cancel, but flip polarity on one and they will. I’m not sure what 180 degrees of phase on a snare drum hit even means

**Keyboard players (and songwriters) of LWMR:** I need to seriously up my keyboard chops this year. 

I’ve been keyboard catting my way through life up to now - mashing out left hand root notes and RH triad shapes to get the rhythm and feel down, then fixing the notes / adding removing midi.  Fine by myself, but infuriating for anyone else in the room. 
 
I’m going to be in some (mostly writing) situations where that’s not going to cut it - I need to be much more fluent.

What are some efficient ways to get there? I’ve tried putting myself through the school of YouTube, but I haven’t found a course prescriptive enough to keep me focused and on track - just loads of disparate technique tutorials, and I don’t know what order to take them in. Also took some lessons, but cost and scheduling were unsustainable.

If it helps, my theory and reading were at one point strong and can probably be dredged back up if needed.

author: austenballard
content:
Speaking as someone who moved to the US, there are a lot of things that will make you miss Europe sorely. Mainly quality of life things, especially if you're moving to Texas (although ATX is not so bad)

First, as people have mentioned, this country is massive. Everything is disproportionately large and far away. You will drive everywhere, which as a German you might not have an issue with, but it gets annoying when you want to pop over to the corner store to grab something and then you remember that doesn't exist, and then you're driving 30 minutes on the highway to the supermarket just to get two things. Normal errands will take you ridiculous amounts of time if you're not in a dense city, particularly east coast cities (NYC ftw)

Next, there's the increasingly Kafkaesque nature of every commercial interaction in the US. People are generally not paid enough relative to their cost of living and are constantly stressed by student debt, credit card debt, auto debt, mortgage debt (if they're lucky enough), etc. As a result, those in many public-facing service jobs do not do their jobs very well. Sorting out a minor problem can easily involve hours of slogging through telephone menus and talking to service reps who can't really help you. An example is it recently took me over a month and 20+ calls to 4 different places to switch my health insurance, which is supposed to take a week at most through an internet portal (Healthcare.gov)

daverat
What does XLR stand for?

ChatGPT
XLR stands for "X-LR" which stands for "eXternal Line Return".

daverat
What is the x series connector by cannon?

The XLR connectors are a series of professional audio connectors produced by Cannon. They are used for balanced audio signals and are widely used in professional audio applications such as microphones, mixers, amplifiers, and speakers. The XLR connectors have three or more pins and are designed to prevent electromagnetic interference and provide stable, reliable audio connections. The most common type of XLR connector has three pins and is known as an XLR3 connector.

author: ALXCPH
content:
at your level i wouldnt worry about singing teachers. What i would worry about is connecting your vocal chords to your ears and brain. technique and breathing isn't something to worry about just yet. A teacher/mentor can be great for guidance. But they can be expensive. A few lessons could def put you in a direction. I would start with ear training learning to hear melodies. Usually when people are unable to hit a note it has less to do with technique and more to do with their ability to decern pitch and notes. 

Starting out is always tough, but start by singing everyday, sing along to your favourite songs. also try and pull up a piano and press a key and then sing the note, then press another key and sing that note, this will teach you to actively target notes with your voice/ears. Learn to sing simple songs on your own without any backing tracks or music. Nursery rhymes are great, they are simple and a lot of people have them internalised. When you get some more confidance, try and have a static chord or note, and sing different notes on top of it and see how the different notes feel / sound and really internalise that.

author: ALXCPH
content:
Let the man sing if he wants to! 🤠 I’d argue that having some musical experience/intuition is 10/10 times not a bad thing. No matter what your job is in the music making process. 

Sure it’s not the engineers job to give advice. But if an artist asks when they are stuck with something being able to communicate at the same language is never a vibe breaker. I’d even argue it could enhance “vibes” or confidence, as long as what is being said makes contextual sense. 

It might be different where you are or at your level. But where I am (lower level 😂) who ever is in the room is involved. And if the process is being respected. I’ve been in so many sessions where I’ve recorded an artist and they ask for a harmony advice, or even if we are vocal producing, being able to quickly sing a line to quickly reference a point in the song is so much. Faster then having to look for it.

author: andrew_yv
content:
An interesting side note re: the psychoacoustic HRTF binaural sound localization discussion from yesterday’s live with @Nomograph Mastering :

I can’t find my source right now but if/when I do I will link it, anyways… A study was conducted wherein moulds were cast of several people’s pinnae (outer ears), these were placed on dummy heads with microphones inside the ‘ear canals’ and recordings were made through each of sound coming from a variety of locations. Some of the subjects were audio professionals and some were lay people.
When the subjects listened back to these recordings, there was significant variance in their ability to localize the sound sources. If I remember correctly, they were generally better at listening through their own pinnae than others were, and audio professionals were a bit better at sound localization in general, particularly in the traditional stereo field. However, the really interesting finding was that there were some pinnae that were universally better or worse. People actually had improved localization through someone else’s pinnae than their own, implying that although we are adapted to our own pinnae, there are material differences that make some better than others for localization of sound.
This is all from memory of reading something a few months ago, so I apologize if there are details that aren’t 100% accurate, but I assure you that the surprising bit is correct!

HRTF-based binaural mixes are not exactly the same thing as dummy head recordings, but I wonder if, in the creation of the aforementioned “baller individual HRTF’s” there might be a place for some optimization beyond the exact copying of an individual’s unique acoustic properties.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I can't stop thinking about this idea of "Why don't you play something that people actually like?"

I personally wrestle a lot with the idea of making music *for* other people. It's simply not very high on my list of priorities. I'd say I'm self-centered in how I approach making music. I'm out to make stuff that *I* want to hear. Things that aren't being represented elsewhere. Flavors I've never heard. I'm not aiming for a broad appeal, but I'm also not shying away from it. I'm just not much of a people pleaser in that regard. I'm in it for the discovery and the exploration and the pleasure of making something that excites me.

I think often about that Steve Jobs sentiment of "People don't know what they want until they see it." I think about that a lot. I trust that if I follow what feels good to *me* then I'll get something valuable out of it, and maybe it'll connect with others. If not, that's alright too. I'll know that I've made something that feels great.

I sometimes worry about this because I've always felt that it puts me at odds with a lot of people out here trying to make excellent records. Sometimes our goals will align, but I just don't feel motivated by the need to appeal to a lot of people and that can also make us diverge.

I guess what I'm trying to say is that there's a different kind of taste that I'm trying to cultivate. It's one that runs parallel to the kind of taste that is good at appealing to a large number of people. I feel as if I'm aiming at an entirely different goalpost from people playing the other game. I want to tickle people in a way that they didn't know they were capable of. That's what's thrilling to me.

author: LAPhill
content:
I'm similar. My projects (active work drive) gets backed up hourly on an incremental scheme to a second internal drive. My system drive gets cloned nightly to another internal drive. If either were to fail, I can immediately swap over. The incremental projects drive has saved me countless times when I need to revert some changes or accidentally write-over a cue when I forget to save-as. 

When projects are done, they get backed up to two duplicate hard drives plus an NAS which has copies of all those hard drives but in one place. 

I haven't done the Backblaze thing yet, so I'm still at risk in the event of fire/flood/zombie attack.

author: shaunobi
content: The second thing though is when the job itself doesn't have the "thing" anymore. Sometimes this is because it morphed - gig work (which I do just at a very large scale) can really suck the joy out of you. Here you are working, but you're also marketing, you're doing sales, you're chasing payment, you're reviewing contracts, you're "presenting" yourself to other people, you're worried about seasonality, you're thinking about healthcare and taxes and retirement, and you're doing it ALL YOURSELF. I don't work for a big company (I run a small one) but my wife does, and the nice thing here is: you just show up and do YOUR job, you're a nurse and you take care of folks, you're an accountant and you reconcile spreadsheets, etc. Instead we do EVERY job with zero economies of scale, and no matter how much you try to "outsource" it, that costs money, it costs oversight and time and initial effort, and in the end it's a lot.

author: Deleted User
content:
I think the bigger question is the lack of money in recording business. 

No tangible way of making real money off of it for most people except those who are landing sync placements, which can really be anyone. The way I see it is sync placement is fulfilling more of the utility aspect of art, while making records for people to listen to is a more artistic endeavor in service of the people that listen to the records. But the reality is that everyone’s streaming and that doesn’t pay. Even with the biggest success- it won’t make money correspondent to the level of success. 

Budget for record production is now more of a PR for their shows or tours. (As far as what I can tell)

So why in a sane mind would anyone spend money on making it other than for their own satisfaction? It’d be insane to see making records as business investment unless you’re really aiming for sync in mind. But then, what most of us fell in love with are the amazing records that we grew up listening to. Maybe a song from a movie occasionally, but probably not quite a track from sports spot nor a jingle. 

At this point, is there really a way to monetize real money from records other than sync? If there can be, what would that be?

author: spectrummasters
content: I have enormous admiration for the top flight audio engineers , sincerely …..and what precipitated my interest in the engineers discussing leveraging their crucial role and upmarketing our skills as a community …..was that . But then it comes back around to “not enough money in record industry to be earned or spent”

author: Deleted User
content:
I only agree halfway. 

What does more value mean in art? How can you be more valuable than to make better music? All of that is vague. 
We all are working on being better, but not all of us are good. 

Those who aren’t good won’t make money- but I think those who are decent should make at least good part time income. 

How good you are is only quantifiable with stream counts. One stream count isn’t more valuable than the other. There isn’t really a straight parallel in what it means to be valuable. 

A song that saved someone’s life from suicide is a one stream count, a song that you didn’t know was playing while the phone was muted is also one stream count. they are both worth $.00437. I’m not saying a song that saved life should make more money. But was that more valuable than a song streamed while the phone was muted? Clearly it is

What does value mean in art? Idk let’s talk about that because we really REALLY need to

That question is intellectual masturbation for most people. For us it’s a legitimate professional concern

but I also don’t know what it’s like to work on a project that makes enough money to pay everybody involved and still make money for the artists yet so my view is premature

author: Deleted User
content:
I think his point isn’t that passion entitles living, but passion becomes a way of manipulation that justifies no pay. 

But to your point regarding leverage, I can’t deny that leverage is important and being good is the best leverage. 

But I think that’s beyond what we’re talking about. Especially in  songwriting land, there are plenty of people who wrote hits that weren’t compensated accordingly. 

Restaurant business sucks, but if you’re good- you can make profits. Each neighborhoods have profit making restaurants. But when it comes to music industry, the proportion of those who actually make money is way low compared to restaurant business. In restaurant business, you still pay the workers regardless. You have to. In music, if the artist isn’t making money then the ones who get hired by artists have no chance of making money

author: Deleted User
content:
And then the counter to that is “then they are not your clients. find those who value you” 

who does? or more like- who is capable of that in this unsustainable business model?

author: Deleted User
content:
how our clients come up with money to pay us is important in order to stay sustainable. because we’re technically in a business of helping another business (artists or labels) make money. 

huge part of our values are tied to our ability to make them money. so of course it matters. 

And our ability to make them money isn’t directly parallel to how good we are at what we do. If they made money, it’s probably because everyone in the team nailed it. But if it’s not making money- that’s not because we sucked at our job. 

Which is why I started getting more involved in artist branding, I wish I could offer enough insights in building a fan base and marketing side of things. Because then I can really be more in control of the situation. 

but even then- there’s not enough money in the market. there’s a long and steep valley of despair between climbing from bottom to top. I do think if there was more money in the pool, the valley of despair wouldn’t be that bad. and in order to pull more money in, crowdfunding could be one of the ways. I wish I can come up with more solutions…

author: Deleted User
content:
For sure- but within the “value you provide” there’s few different categories of it. and the main thing people consider first is “can I make that money back” 

I wish I was competent enough to make that money back for them, but at the same time my service is still service for them. The value I can actually guarantee to provide for them

The tough thing is I wouldn’t hire me for the money I charge from a clients’ POV because of the lack of ROI. I’d go DIY. But the thing is people are still wanting to hire me to do that work. It is a weird in between to be in. I don’t think I should be hungry enough to cut down on my price, but I also don’t think I have enough track record for people to justify spending the face value of my “labor” itself.

author: Deleted User

That’s where I’m at precisely. Last year, I turned down more than I took in until the summer. Then I decided to do free work to improve my portfolio.

author: Deleted User
content:
Definitely something I’ve considered over and over. I mean, if I am too expensive then it really is the reason. I’m hearing this from those whom I’ve worked with before. 

But as you mentioned, you work in an industry that is more profitable as far as my knowledge (games). There isn’t much reason for them to question ROI. I don’t say this to invalidate your point, I think we’re just in a different playing field with different rules. 

If I lowered my price to $300 a song, I’d have no problem getting work. But I’d be making less. And of course maybe that’s what I need to do to get to the point I want to be, but I’d rather do it for no money and have more freedom in controlling my portfolio and having more potential long term returns. 

All of your points are valid points though

author: spectrummasters
content: Speaking of drum samples ......The drums from Rihanna’s umbrella are a logic Apple loop , it’s in everyone’s loop browser🤣 .: when it comes to samples . I started with an mpc . I built my kits from sampling my fav records and finding isolated hits. It’s an art and it takes love of the record......but I’d recommend going this way with it .....I think @Deleted User .....said it right. The internet is awash with sample packs that are just the same hits renamed. You can grab all the OG Roland and linn drum kits in seconds these days......and all the processed versions of them since . If  you sample things yourself you’re curating as you go and this will imo , make it different and valuable. D’angelo voodoo, Dre 2001; Wookie and James brown gave me all I needed for drums for the longest .

author: peterlabberton
content:
Alright frens, seeking… wisdom? Advice? A gig? (Lol.)

I’ve wanted to live in nyc my entire adult life and never have—it’s never made sense to do it career-wise and probably never really will. But every time I’m there I feel totally at home and happy and excited in a way I don’t anywhere else. I spent a summer there several years ago and always linger as long as I can whenever I can, have close friends there (not in music), end up there usually a couple times a year and relish it every time. I feel like I know it as well as is possible for never having been a resident.

I know the music biz there is pretty much defunct (at least compared to LA), and I really *really* don’t want to repeat the emotional and financial ruin that I experienced moving to LA and restarting everything 6 yrs ago… but from a non-career perspective it’s where I want to be.

All that said, I’m in it to fucking win it in LA for my career—though with an eye for sure on getting to a point where I can relatively comfortably make that move.

Any wisdom/experience on making a mid-career move like this from folks here? I’m 35 yrs old, some decent credits but not major traction yet, in a basically married but not actually married relationship with a school principal who is into the idea of a move there as well (though our finances are totally separate and I for sure need to earn!), no kids or desire/plan to have kids.

Any benchmarks/goals that might be reasonable to aim for before seriously starting to make moves on this? I’d do it tomorrow if I could, but would also stay in LA for 5+ more years no prob to set things up properly. Even open to things like a podcast (/radio?/other audio prod) gig to help smooth the transition if that’s reasonable to find and lucrative enough—but what I’m really looking for is how to think of this as a full time freelance record maker. Or if someone on here secretly is hiring for staff gigs at Electric Lady, plz lmk 😉

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
I'll be 30 in October. My wife and I haven't explicitly put it off the table but she has a medical condition (that I don't super want to get into here) that would make us lean towards a surrogate or adoption if we did want kids. That plus the amount of time we are currently putting into our careers puts a few large roadblocks since in the current state of things, the only extra time in our day would be cutting out sleep altogether. I know that's part of becoming a parent and they're only an infant for so long, but before it becomes a more serious conversation between us, we'd want to figure out how to get more of our time back.

I think we have time to decide still but for now it seems like anytime I talk to someone who is already a parent about it they push the topic. I didn't really think that I'd have this conversation in here tonight but here we are 😂

content:

Writers cancel, mix parts don’t turn up. There’s always something to be done, whether that’s printing stems or making song starters for an upcoming session so I roll with it like that.

Just reading @shaunobi posts above, I wondered if there was some sustainable middle ground I could find, but whenever I’ve tried scheduling an hour by hour day in my calendar, I’ve more or less ignored it because inspiration hit in the first hour and I had to ride the wave. Or a mix wasn’t clicking, so it got extra hours or whatever.

author: LAPhill
content:
I've walked away from exactly 1 project in my career. Because life is too short and it was a bridge I had no qualms about burning. 

In general yes, powering through can be a better preservationist strategy for your career, but you only have so much to give. On difficult projects, sometimes the thing that keeps me going is a second project. Even though that's even more work, having something enjoyable to jump to when I'm running on empty can give me enough fuel to keep going. Relegate it to the sidelines and mitigate its impact on your psyche. This does not at all mean do anything less than your 100%, but try to adjust your schedule in a way that allows joy and fun to come through in other places.

author: AJ
content:
Despite what I just said, a part of my results oriented struggle comes from my expectations with music. Gave up the idea of doing it for a living, but I still aim on finding a small audience some day. Have had people ask why I spend so much without that audience. 

But right now? Making the best music possible keeps me sane while I work on establishing my career. In this instance, my hope comes from two things: the fact that I'm doing what I need to be happy, and that the productivity in my professional life stays in tact with that.  

I also that's think the main way younger folks can keep their hope. A shocking amount of folks in my age range don't know what they like about life. We need to give folks the ability to find those outlets (whatever those look like). Without it, things are bound to be monotonous. Those circumstances aren't likely to inspire hope in anyone.

author: Josh Bowman
content: Biggest thing for any post audio mix- find out the delivery specs before you mix it (ie broadcast or web only, surround or stereo or both) and setup your mix so your music, dialog, and sfx masters are doing any buss processing and leave your master/mix buss clean aside from final limiter. You wanna make sure the stems add up to the final mix exactly if possible to avoid future shenanigans. Label things very clearly. Otherwise just make it sound good! A lot of ad/agency people like the dialog pretty hot I find.  I’m actually not sure what OMV means. But I’ve been out of the ad mixing game for a few years so maybe I’m blanking. Did it full time briefly tho and delivered a bunch of network stuff so 🤷‍♂️

author: Josh Bowman
content: I still have a toe in- but don’t go looking actively for post gigs. I’d say 85% of my work is music mixing, and the rest is tv/ad stuff when it comes up. but doing it full time as a staff engineer wasnt for me. Lots of “dog and pony shows”  for clients… annoying agency people, plus I was getting fat from all the catering 😂 If I ever pursue it actively again it will be on my own and not working for a studio. I mainly just don’t love working for other people I guess might actually be the take away

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
The value in ALL pop culture is, in general, front loaded.  Across his entire career Rod is reported as earning $300 Million from all recordings, tours, and etc. He squeezed the best out of it then. Being "featured" in GTA or any other modern revival is worth something, but it's not going to net anything near original hit earnings. Especially with royalties still dwindling, in general (aka smaller pie than pre-2004 and more content dividing it up). 

Rod played the game well and is loving this.  I don't think they will roupe.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
That's the thing...  I think the earnings of 20th century recordings are going to diminish as the generations die.  Currently catalogs from popular music of the 1940s and 50s...  this peer group is almost extinct.  In 20yrs those catalogs will not have a multiple value, but it will be a diminished return (less than 1x) ....  not a growth (greater than 1x multiple).  

If Rod Stewarts catalog generated $300 Million during the height of his popularity (including tours)...   The value of his catalog over the decades would be a fraction of that.  To recoup $100 Million would require $10 Million x 10yrs in ROYALTY alone to break even. He (reportedly) earned $7 Million from his music in 2013.  So the ROI couldn't profit until 2037 (without touring income).  His fanbase will be effectively extinct by 2040 and it's going to be hard to break 1980s trends on future generations.  You'll get some novelty bumps but I don't know how many Kate Bush moments investors can bank on.  Seems more lottery and less solid investment

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Not sure where to put this so we’ll start here and maybe we can migrate it if it lands in any way

Had a great call last week with @Josh. We talked about a bunch of stuff but one of the themes we explored was the idea that one needs a “portfolio” of slick & great sounding work to get hired

Once you’ve decided that then it becomes the focus, and changes the way things feel and the way decisions about time, who you work with etc get made. Concepts like “I’ll suck it up and work for free but *then* I will have a singular “good track” for my portfolio”. Of course there are exceptions but it feels to me that there’s something very constricting and materialist about this way of being in the world. There can be a tension between what the artist wants or what the song wants to be and what makes you look “good” in your portfolio - they want mono and grimy but you want wide/lush/impressive

In our jam I proposed a kind of thought experiment, an end of the line or extreme of the “need portfolio” way of thinking…

So let’s say you are here, a young writer, producer, mixer. You’ve been doing it 3 or 4 years. You feel that one of the reasons you are not getting hired, getting shots or getting paid well is that there isn’t a body of work for a potential client to judge you by. Ok, here’s comes the magic trick. I’m going to grant you a genie wish portfolio! 5 killer tracks with  great collaborators. Not hot 100 #1 but the kind of work that you really feel would represent you best in the world. Boom. There it is…

So now what? You get some DMs and sessions start happening. But you’re not ready. You’re not fit for game day. You’re in over your head, and don’t have the fluency, the experience, the reps and the humblings that build a great music business pro. In short you’re not ready for the opportunities the genie wish portfolio granted you

author: Deleted User
content:
when we think of how language and words get created out of necessity, we can also use that to work our way back and analyze why certain words become popular or lost its use over time. especially with internet, language started driving a good part of pop culture. we don’t want the words to limit our expressions, we want words to enable more articulate expressions and thinking -> both are happening from what I see. 

Why does the new generation feel the need to minimize and maximize everything? Why can’t we spend our effort into exploring everything in between? 

Do everything in between come with labels or do they become lengthy sentences and paragraphs? 

I think the answer to all of this is complexity of life that us humans brought onto ourselves. That is the cycle of “why older generation can’t understand newer generations”

older generations make the world “better” - (technologies and advancement of civilization & cultural understanding ) for the new generation. But what this “better” comes with many times though, is complicated soup of mess. This causes overload in young people’s minds trying to make sense of this world. Many or most don’t have the patience to keep on trying to explore the nuances in between. Or can’t afford to take the time / invest the energy to do so. I believe the lack of dimensions in the new generation’s language is a product of this. 

@NoahNeedleman said older, less nuanced in opinion & younger, less nuanced in language. I believe both are true for both younger and older people *if they ended up giving up trying to dig deeper to explore and ponder on “everything in between”*. I don’t think age has anything to do with it. It’s just that the disparities between those who had the patience for nuance vs those who gave up trying become more apparent as people get older.

author: peterlabberton
content:
Having just bought my first place with my girlfriend, AND having listened to that Daily episode, I definitely think it can be awesome but isn’t *always* awesome. We were very close to backing out of the process, until we saw the place we got, and the determining factor for us was that it had an ADU, and was in our budget. There’s work (and money to sink into said work!) we need to do, but once we have a tenant in, even conservatively I think it will either cover our mortgage, or come close to it. (It’s very likely NOT going to cover tax and insurance, but that’s more than fine.) We also were in a really fantastic first time homeowners program, which allowed us to put only 2% down, and gave us a grant for another percentage point down. This is all helped IMMENSELY by my girlfriend both having a real deal grownup salaried job and having just about perfect credit. But it’s going to allow us to build wealth through the house, and allow me to build my studio space, AND if we ever want to leave LA, because our interest rate is comparatively great, we’d just keep it and rent both units.

So, TLDR, I don’t think it’s a slam dunk always great idea, but I think if you can finagle the situation to work for you, it can be really smart.

Also, my entire family on my mom’s side has been school teachers/librarians/pastors/professors (so doing fine but by no means rich), but my parents and their parents were both able to ride California real estate into a very comfortable place in retirement.

author: gatewoodsensei
content:
Very interesting question. 
#1 ). I’d lean moreso cutting edge to classic. But I’d give about a 7. I think the cutting edge stuff is what pushes society forward but you need to understand the *why* things were and are the way they are before you can actually begin moving things around. Kind of like coloring outside of the lines, one must first understand why the lines are there and what the lines represent. 

#2). I’m a 0 here in the beginning and then branching out in the later. I think it’s smart to become known for something and once you’ve established yourself, then branch out. Personally, I burned myself out trying to be everything to everyone. Trying to solve EVERY problem for every company limited my knowledge to fix niche problems in business thus limiting my income potential. 

#3). I go 10 easy. Long term success breeds *predictable* easy wins. I love the quote “it took me 10 years to become an overnight success”. Practicing a shot, riff, sales pitch, etc for years in the long term makes short term wins more sustainable and accessible.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Late to the party. I do like this question. 

For me #1 would probably be a 5. Something special about dancing with an idea that's been around for centuries or millennia even, but also very exciting to explore the cutting edge. Hard for me to pick one over the other.

#2 I'd go with a 7 maybe. If I knew more than anyone else about one thing I'm not sure that would maximize my wellbing / happiness. One of my great joys in life is to pursue the myriad of curiosities that bubble up in me. I would hate to neglect them. Besides there's a lot of cool shit out there.

#3 My default here is a 10. As much as that has been a gift and helped me navigate my career I'm not sure it's best for my wellbeing. My gf is probably closer to a 0 here and she is generally happier than I am and very successful in her career. Perhaps there's a more emotionally regulated way to view the long-term but I see risk, upside, downside.. If I'm not careful it can induce a lot of stress. I think I'd rather crank the slider closer to zero the older I get.

author: Deleted User
content:
I loved the analysis, I had thoughts about a few points he mentioned. 

1. Paradox of climbing up to the highest level
Could Michael Jordan have become Michael Jordan if it wasn’t for the feeling of someone chasing behind him to become one of the greatest of all time? There is only one Michael Jordan, and can anyone else be that one and only without going through what he has put himself through? 

2. Acceptance vs Dissatisfaction
I think the dilemma here is between satisfaction and acceptance vs beating. I don’t think one or the other is necessarily the answer, but I think a good place to be is finding acceptance in where I am right now while still beating on myself to keep on improving to the highest level I could be. 

3. Potential
This is a crazy concept to me. Who is anyone to evaluate someone’s ceiling of improvement? Spider defined the meaning of ‘potential’ perfectly in my opinion. Not his exact works but; one’s capable/willing range of adaptation. Did the professor in Whiplash really expand his students’ potential in this sense? 

4. Abusive Internal voice 
I love how he saw the professor as our internal voice. And it made perfect sense to why I was so obsessed with this movie and the character. He was myself to me all along. I went back and forth over and over on whether this relationship was worth it to either of them. I think perhaps limited to this particular two people, because they had common goals/interests and made it happen. 

5. Joy?
I feel that this is the most simple and complex out of all things here. Can anyone NOT experience any frustration while trying to get better at something? If the answer is no, is there a way to better manage the frustration? 

Pursuit vs Result, our brain works the most consistently when we look towards pursuit. Result feels good but not for long, but what if the result meant more than just the goal being achieved? What if the “result” portion leads to another pursuit after another?

author: Matt Huber
content:
So, first of all, thanks to the buds here who appreciate what I’ve posted in the past.

Second of all, my thoughts on this:
 
I have a personal rule that I will NOT post anything that feels like EFFORT or out of a motivation to game the algo. If I’m “making content” and notice that I’m doing so out of a place that is less than genuine, I will just delete and move on. 

For me, the “mix tips” thing came out of a sincere place of excitement and passion. I would, as a growing mix engineer, stumble upon something that excited me, and I would find myself wanting to turn around to the people in the room to share…well, there’s almost never anyone in the room with me. So, I channeled that passion and excitement in a genuine way to share with the small community of mixers, mastering engineers and producers that I knew on IG. 

At the beginning of my career on to the middle of my career, that became a very fruitful source of business for me - people who followed me on IG, who enjoyed my posts, and began to view me as someone who MIGHT know a thing or two about mixing. 

As my career has developed and my clientele has growing, that has become less important, but it was absolutely pivotal in helping me build a deep bench of great clients, both indie and signed. 

But…I NEVER did it for that reason. It was always (and continues to be) a genuine result of my passion for what I do.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Ah that makes sense for you!! I see a lot of people successfully doing media planning (release scheduling etc) with ChatGPT now - that seems to be one of the areas where AI can do a pretty stellar job, but you'd still need someone to look over/execute.

Overall it sounds like you might need someone with a pretty broad skillset. I'd look at an ex youtuber/part time youtuber in your position probably, but few of them have the technical chops to make lyric videos or film acoustic videos to a high standard - I'd suggest those are two different roles, unless you get very lucky. The cinematography and lyric video making (motion graphics) are also considered more high paying skillsets, so even if you do find someone with the entire range of skills, you might end up paying more than splitting them up.

Overall your plan sounds good! Sounds great that you're willing to be hands off, that will pay immensely in my experience. 

Re: meetings, I don't really have an approach apart from avoiding them as much as possible. Try to schedule group calls when it's possible to multitask. What kind of meetings do you have with your team now?

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Totally. Definitely interesting. 

My feeling is that you need massive cultural power and dominance to define something generic. That type of power is almost impossible to gain now, while Taylor Swift might technically have more fans than MJ now due to the internet & population growth it's still not the type of relative cultural dominance MJ had, and definitely not like the Beatles. You'd need a lot more stardom and exposure over a lot longer of a time, and even then, there's just more music now. More segmentation.

author: Rukie
content:
the word “emotion” needs a better definition sometimes in the space we are in. 

Emotion isn’t necessarily something that you are always aware of “feeling”. Some reactions are merely state of mind, until it is given a name. Some reactions are visceral because of what the chemicals do to our body. 
sometimes, it’s neither visceral nor label-able. Which makes us assume that it’s not a feeling or emotion. But can we really differentiate emotions and thoughts? What exactly would differentiate them? 

On the other hand, there is music that pushes more, versus music that pulls more. 

Just like how audio is bipolar, we can’t have connections just be a one way communication. Tame Impala is a type of music that pulls. You don’t know why, but you just want to know “what was that song? I GOTS TO FIND OUT”. 

Push is more like… “I can’t unhear it” a lot of Pop hits are push with some pull factor. 

the ones that make you bummed out that you couldn’t shazam are ones that pull you in. it’s a slight push that gets you listening, and the rest of it is just pulling you in. (my own reaction when I first heard tame impala and couldn’t find out whose song it was)

Culturally, I think the love for (dreamy sound) can be explained with a desire to escape reality. 

So really, the emotional reaction is that “it transports me into a different space”. My theory on “why do people like that feeling?” is that many people aren’t happy with the reality of our lives because of economy and what not. And the idea of “escape from reality” became more and more a viable thing for us to want after experiencing digital devices and internet.

author: itaylerner
content:
2 cents: I think it’s a “stars have to align” kind of thing (That’s why there’s a million artists but only 1 Beyoncé and 1 Post Malone) That combo of unique pov + excellent artistic taste + ability to express it all… it’s rare, to say the least.

I personally think, generally speaking, that a producers job is less about helping an artist craft their pov and more about supporting them in their process of uncovering and expressing it, Unless you’re extreeemely close with that artist. it’s really their job, as a human first, to process their experiences and develop their unique perspective. To become the most whole version of themselves, imho. 

Your job as a producer is to create a safe and encouraging space where they can explore and express it, say scary things, move forward in their ideas. It’s also your job to then facilitate the process at every stage, musically and otherwise, to make sure the execution is as good as it can possibly be. But the artist is the artist, it all comes from them at the end of the day.

author: kieronmenzies
content: In my experience, every artist has a very specific "point of view" with varying degrees of how well they know and/or express it. Sometimes we're in the studio with very specific goals in mind. For example: to sound like the the musical equivalent of the artist's Pinterest board, to sound like two of the artist's favorite artists had a baby together, to sound like the last album but different, or just to make our own version of an already-established style of music. On the other hand, sometimes we're searching and digging and discovering to see what happens. In these production sessions it may seem like there are no goal posts -- the goal is there but it's just not readily apparent. Maybe the artist doesn't seem like they even know what they want but they do and they'll know it when they hear it. And then once (if) you get to that aha! moment, it's like hitting something hard when digging for treasure in the sand. Maybe it's just a rock, or maybe it's coprolite or maybe, just maybe it's a chest full of gold coins which you can then hand over to the labels, managers, lawyers and streaming services while you keep a couple of the remaining fragments of copper for yourself.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I think there’s a danger in assuming those that are successful didn’t have it hard.
2 quick stories that have shaped my career:

very early on when I was recruited to play in a band in Australia. Sold my car, got rid of my apartment, and flew out to Melbourne. Band had a moment but I got tossed out just as the song was going number 1. Had no money to get home, no where to stay, and was literally 23 living on our producers couch in a country about as far from home as possible. And I called my pop, basically telling him how bummed/scared/fucked I was. And he goes “you know, I just got off the phone with **** (a very famous actor friend of ours). If there’s anyone that had it all, you’d think it was him. Big career, wife on the cover of sports illustrated swimsuit edition, fans everywhere. But it turns out his Dad just passed, his wife is cheating on him, and if this new show doesn’t get picked up they might lose the house they just bought. EVERYONE has their share of crap they have to deal with, give or take, no matter how easy it looks from the outside. Life isn’t about what happens to you, it’s about how you deal with what happens to you. Figure out a way to make the most of what’s going on”. For some reason, knowing that EVERYONE’s life sucks to some degree, was immensely helpful in getting me back on my feet.

The other was a year or two later, when I started tuning vocals for Rob Cavallo. One of his wrecking crew of session musicians had been in a band with a huge hero of mine, who had sadly took his own life mid way through making his second record. I asked the guy if there was anything he could tell me about working with said hero, and he said “he was the best musician I’ve ever met. Whatever instrument you played he was better at it than you were within 10 minutes of picking it up. But he seemed to think he was the only guy that ever got a raw deal from the music industry”.
