author: Chad Rodgers
content:
I like the idea of agency as practice. A really talented artist I've been working with recently is young and very new to the industry. They don't know much about being a recording artist, how publishing works, how the business side of things goes down, or what kind of a team they need to build around themselves etc. So I suggested some further reading, shared some of my experience and gave them some tips (as I always try to do with younger artists, to do what you say @spectrummasters and support them). Their response was 'Honestly my manager can do all of this for me, I just want to focus on the music, it's all too complicated and goes over my head'.

So what can you do 🤷‍♂️ 

This, I guess, is one example of someone who could really do with some personal agency. If their manager walks, they're a bit fucked. There are thousands of other young artists out there who will be actively educating themselves on the business, joining Discord groups like this for furthering their networks and education, and proactively looking at how the arc of their career can be navigated 'by them', not 'to them'. This kind of proactive attitude would immediately gift the artist I'm working with a leg-up, giving them an advantage over peers, with a higher chance of success. The more they do this, the more control they have over their career. It's a win-win.

So back to a more definition-based view of the term 'agency', or like I said before 'nous', a lot of folks could do with more of it and I totally see both sides of this conversation. It's good to explore the cultural and societal effects on something like this as nothing exists in a vacuum, but on a general, everyday level, it's SUPER useful and important to try and exercise control over outcomes. Is the opposite of agency apathy?

author: earwormfarmer
content: Too much sub for bands that don’t need it is one of my biggest pet peeves. Saw Big Thief a few years ago and the sub in the kick drum was absolutely goosed. The room couldn’t handle it so all that  low information was ringing and decaying really slowly. Was a bummer since it seemed to really mess with their internal groove which is not a super  kick drum driven thing! Some of their faster songs seemed like a big struggle to lock in.

author: bobby k
content:
question for the class.

this month has turned into a brilliant crazy mess of a couple exciting opportunities with imminent deadlines all hitting at once, and a certain person in my life is less than thrilled with the ebbing and flowing of it all. obviously we try to keep general boundaries throughout the year, but...i'd like to think these can be bent when they need to. instead of sharing in my excitement about getting to work on cooler stuff, and generally making more income than times prior, my other half has been pretty upset about it all. 

what has been your experience with this kind of tension? everyone is different, but i do think hearing other's stories might help me better understand this challenge.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Does anyone have a mid-priced webcam that they're very happy with? My previous cam died and I'm looking for a replacement for video calls. Here are my requirements:

1. 1080p (Don't need 4k)
2. Good microphones
3. USB-C connections
4. Does not require me to install a ton of superfluous software to access it's camera controls.

I don't need anything elite here. I'm merely doing video calls, but I need it to sound good and do it's job with minimal fuss.

author: Slow Hand
content: MuseScore has become a tool that I use regularly. It may not be a fully featured notation program on par with Sibelius or Dorico or Finale (RIP), but it's getting there while being significantly more intuitive. Notation software has been a design nightmare, and Tantacrul has been ringing that bell for years now. So much so that someone finally hired him to lead the MuseScore team and put his money where his mouth is.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: Hey guys, so I wear a lot of different hats in my day to day, as I'm sure a lot of you do. Does anyone else experience a kind of uncertainty/mild anxiety about their work that might derive from the fact that you're not really specialized in a certain area? I feel like I'm not always as excited or confident about getting into a certain task not only because I know i'm not very good at it yet (which i know is all relative, I could still be exactly what someone else needs for something), but also because I know others are out there, sometimes in my personal circle, who are much better? For a little added detail, my fulltime career is as a voice actor, but I love mixing, and sometimes I produce some baby artists, engineer ADR and video game/commercial voiceover. This week i was asked to dialog edit an animated film, I have to comp vocals for someone's song, and there's always a litany of othere stuff, none of which I ever feel prepared to do so the work usually takes longer than I know it should. Maybe the answer is simply to stop trying to be everything to everyone, but honestly I'm terrified to put all my eggs into the voiceover basket even though it's what I've got the most momentum with.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: And my main work sustains me just fine, but just like music work, it's not guaranteed. I audition for a living, it can be really lumpy income, but I'm in a good spot.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I disagree, personally, about the reaching out part. 

I think there’s a lot of merit to positing what you’re up to if you’re a working musician / engineer. People hire busy people. It’s a weird thing. 

Also it’s a way for people to be reminded you exist. And I believe you can do it in an authentic and non frustrating way, as horrendous as social media can be.

author: Jamie Donnelly
content:
Yes! 

I have really vivid memories of reading it. It came out when I was just starting the second year of my degree programme, and I was sent away to work by my employer. First time working away from home. I spent every night in the hotel reading the book while listening to the albums he was talking about. Opened my ears to lots of fabulous music!
